urn:contentItem:5TMP-R3H1-JB20-G4Y0-00000-00Apple Shares Slide; Florida Goes to the Polls; U.S. China Trade Tensions; Health Care is the Number One Issue for Voters2018-11-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTKevin Kelly, James Freeman, Ted Yoho, Joseph GalatiNEWSFinancial110202cb.231Apple Shares Slide; Florida Goes to the Polls; U.S. China Trade Tensions; Health Care is the Number One Issue for VotersMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Kristina Partsinevelos

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. TGIF.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Friday, November 2nd.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the button right now.

Major market moves this morning -- Apple shares the story of the day. It is down on weak revenue guidance and on the announcement that the company is no longer going to be providing unit sales. So we will not know specific unit sales on a quarterly basis anymore. The technology giant at risk of losing a $1-trillion market valuation with today's move. It is down 5.25 percent.

The other big story of the market, of course, is the October jobs report. Yes, it is jobs Friday right here. The expectation is for 190,000 jobs added to the economy in the month of October with the unemployment rate holding steady at 3.7 percent which is a multi-decade low.

We will take a look at what this means for the midterm elections and the market. Of course, the midterms now four days away.

Check out futures this morning. Even with the 5.5 percent selloff in Apple, we're looking at a rally of 260 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. It's going to be up about 1 percent right out of the gate this morning. The S&P 500 is expected to be up 21 points. That's three- quarters of 1 percent. And the Nasdaq right now up 15 points, a quarter of a percent on the Nasdaq.

This after another day of gains yesterday. This is the third day of gains for the markets yesterday. The Dow Industrials up 265 points at the close. All the major indices finished at their highs of the -- or near their highs of the session. The Dow, S&P up better than 1 percent; the Nasdaq up 1.75 percent, 128 points higher yesterday for the Nasdaq.

Markets this morning across the globe higher -- FT 100 up three-quarters of a percent, 53 points higher in London; one-and-a-third percent higher in Paris on the CAC 40 at 66 points higher; and the DAX index in Germany up 172 points, that's 1.5 percent higher in Germany.

In Asia, overnight gains across the board -- check it out. Best performer Hong Kong -- Hang Seng index up better than 4 percent overnight.

On the earnings front, we are watching Alibaba earnings later this morning. We will hear from oil giants and Dow components, ExxonMobil and Chevron. We'll have those numbers and analysis.

Right now, it's really Apple which is a big focus but these are coming out soon.

China trade in focus -- this was important yesterday in the markets. President Trump spoke with China's president Xi Jinping and apparently there was progress in the trade dispute from what we understand from that phone call. It definitely helped markets rally yesterday in the middle of the day.

Here's what IAC chairman Barry Diller told me about China's trade practices yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARRY DILLER, CHAIRMAN, IAC: I am not a proponent of quote, "trade wars" - - their trade practices have to change, trying to pick trade wars. If you let an unfettered trade war actually take place, which is in our control, it would be disastrous for everybody.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest coming up. More of Barry Diller this morning.

All those stories coming up this Friday morning. And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman; and Benchmark managing partner, Kevin Kelly. Great to see you this morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: So Alibaba is actually up right now 5 percent in the premarket because they actually beat pretty significantly on the revenues and on their bottom line. They have a revenue forecast cut on macroeconomic conditions though. So even though they did beat, so it was initially up 5 percent, now it seems like it's coming down a little bit because probably of this forecast of macro concerns.

And one of the things they're actually talking about is also the money they need to spend into their streaming services. So in order for them to be the Netflix of China, they're indicating they need to spend significantly more on their content.

BARTIROMO: So it is losing ground quickly.

KELLY: It is losing ground quickly. But they said their annual active buyers are actually up 23 percent so they're doing very well.

BARTIROMO: So the numbers are better than expected --

(CROSS TALKING)

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- but they're going to be having to see costs go up.

KELLY: Yes. They're seeing costs go up, and also they're guiding revenues down because of macro conditions. So unless Trump and President Xi Jinping have beautiful chocolate cake, Alibaba is very concerned.

BARTIROMO: The chocolate cake moment.

We've got a lot coming up this morning. Part two of my exclusive interview with the chairman and senior executive of both IAC and Expedia Group. That's Barry Diller. He weighs in on Amazon, Google, U.S. trade relations with China as well as General Electric as well. You don't want to miss a moment of it. So do stay with us for that interview.

But we want to get to Apple because the stock is trading down this morning on disappointing guidance. It is on track to shave about 85 points from the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Stock right now down 5.5 percent as CEO Tim Cook said that the company will no longer give unit sales figures in future reports. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: This is like if you go to the market and you push your cart up to the cashier and she says or he says how many units you have in there? It doesn't -- it doesn't matter a lot, how many units there are in there in terms of the overall value of what's in the cart.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Interesting. Well, I can understand the analogy. Does it not matter? I would imagine analysts --

KELLY: No. I think it matters.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: If your investors tell you it matters, then it matters. Whatever your messaging is -- more information is better. You can't be in the news business and say I want less information from the world's $1 trillion company.

BARTIROMO: Right.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": No, I'm not going to say that.

MCDOWELL: Ok.

FREEMAN: Obviously, you do want more information and as people think about the company's future, they want to see in each segment how it's doing. But I would say in his defense, this has never been a company that -- where it's about volume. Apple really has not been the big volume producer. That's the android universe.

So what Apple sells is to a smaller market but to a much more lucrative market, very high-priced, very high-margin products. So if you're seeing what you want to see on the revenue and the earnings from each of these products --

KELLY: I beg to differ.

(CROSS TALKING)

FREEMAN: I don't know that it's the end of the world that you don't see how many devices.

KELLY: It's not about that. It's not even about the iPhone anymore. It's 60 percent of sales now. It used to be a lot more of that. It actually used to be 75 percent of sales. But we need to get unit sales on Mac books, on their home pods, on their watches -- that is the next leg of growth for them and attribution into their ecosystem.

So the problem is that they missed on the services side. In order for the services side to grow, we need to know how many units they're selling of each product line. So I need to know what's in that shopping cart because they missed on the services.

They had less than $10 billion. They're saying that it's $10 billion. It was actually less than that. It was $9.981 billion when every analyst across the street had at least $10.18 billion.

MCDOWELL: We should point out that services --

(CROSS TALKING)

KELLY: So that's the biggest issue.

FREEMAN: The market agrees with you. Over time, I think this is probably not going to be --

BARTIROMO: You're calling this a miss.

KELLY: No -- but this is a miss. They missed on unit sales for iPhones which is 60 percent of the revenue. And then they're refreshing all their Macbook Pros and their watches and now we're not going to get guidance into that?

MCDOWELL: The growth -- they missed on the forecast for the December quarter that it was -- they show slowing growth there. That was the revenue forecast. In terms of the services business, we should just point out that's app store sales, Apple pay use, music streaming, subscriptions stuff like that -- revenue growth there was up 17 percent. That's slower in recent quarters.

When you have a valuation like this, you have to -- your growth rates need to be bigger and bigger and bigger, not smaller and smaller and smaller.

KELLY: That's it. And listen Morgan Stanley just downgraded the price target from $247 to $226 and their analyst has been very good on the stock. You had BAML -- Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch downgrade their price target to $223 --

BARTIROMO: Don't forget what Dan Miles -- I know I keep saying this -- but he was right. I mean what's your take on inventory because Dan said that in the second quarter inventory was up 89 percent. And that also goes hand in hand with the unit sales because if you've got all this inventory, first you've got get rid of that before you actually start producing more.

KELLY: That's it. And they're not expecting to sell more that's why you're seeing them increase the price of their products -- ok.

BARTIROMO: Right.

KELLY: And then they also had their component costs go down. So that's great. But I don't invest in the stock market looking in the rearview mirror. I invest looking forward.

BARTIROMO: Let's look forward to the jobs report. That's another major story this morning because the jobs report is coming out in an hour-and-a- half.

We want to check out one of the election's most pivotal states this morning and that's Florida.

Kristina Partsinevelos as has more from the Sunshine State this morning. And Kristina -- it's been a good jobs market in Florida as well. Good morning to you.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning. And you're right.

Yes, it is a pivotal race. It's a swing state. And this year is no different. We have a lot of people looking at the governor's race and the senate race.

We have former President Obama who is going to be here in Miami where I am right now on Route 1. It's very early in the morning so it's still quite dark out. He's throwing his support behind the Dems. You've got Andrew Gillum who's running for governor and then incumbent Bill Nelson who is also going for Senate. So those are the two candidates that former President Obama is supporting.

If we take a look at the Real Clear Politics polls and average multi-polls (ph) that we're seeing across the board for governor in Florida, you're seeing a slight lead, a little bit less than 3 percent for Gillum. Gillum is 39 years old, a progressive, mayor of Tallahassee -- pretty much pushing for higher minimum wage and higher corporate taxes.

He is going against Republican Ron DeSantis who has the full support of President Trump. They will be together on Saturday in Pensacola. And you have Ron DeSantis who is an advocate for gun control. There hasn't been a Democrat who's been elected for the governor's race since 1994.

And we switch over to Senate race which is also closely watched -- we look at the polls over there from Real Clear Politics again, you're seeing as of this morning less than 2 percent lead for Bill Nelson. So Bill Nelson, 75 years old, a centrist -- he's pushing for a ban on assault rifles.

And he's going against Governor Rick Scott who's very familiar here because he served two terms as governor. He wants to continue his political life which is why he's running for Senate. A lot can happen here.

We have former President Obama here, in Georgia on Friday and in Chicago on Sunday. Lots of movement in Florida and we're going to be here.

Back to you -- guys.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's really an important race. Kristina -- thank you. We'll keep checking back. Kristina Partsinevelos is in Miami this morning.

Joining us right now is Florida Congressman Ted Yoho. He's running for office in Florida's third congressional district and is on the Foreign Affairs and Agriculture House Committees. Sir -- it's good to have you on this morning.

REP. TED YOHO (R), FLORIDA: Hi.

BARTIROMO: Thanks very much for joining us.

YOHO: Good morning -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: How do you feel going into the midterms in terms of your own prospects?

YOHO: I feel really good. We've got a lot of momentum on the ground. We've got people out door-knocking, making phone calls. We're doing rallies and coffees all over the district.

The momentum is on our side that we're seeing. And I think you're going to see it carry through the governor's race and the Senate race with Rick Scott.

BARTIROMO: Well, it doesn't look like that. We're looking at the numbers. And if you believe the polls, it looks like Gillum is in the lead and even Nelson is in the lead. What do you think about that?

YOHO: Well, we got internal polls-- we've got internal polls that show different. If you go back to the last presidential election, they had Hillary Clinton leading the day of the election. So I think there's a lot of movement on the ground. I think you're going see this.

And then you've got our governor's race -- you know, you've got a guy that's under FBI investigation and he's got a liberal progressive agenda that wants to roll back what Rick Scott has done.

And then you compare Rick Scott's record with Bill Nelson is just like a place holder and he's not accomplished a whole lot. Rick Scott has created 1.6 million jobs in this state, lowered taxes and we've got one of the best ratings, if not the best rating in the country for a state.

Rick Scott has done an awesome job. He'll do that in the senate. And I can't wait for him to get up there and work with him.

MCDOWELL: Congressman -- it's Dagen McDowell. The unemployment rate in the state of Florida is below the national average. It was 3.5 percent in Florida.

YOHO: It sure is.

MCDOWELL: Rick Scott took that economy to a trillion dollars in terms of its value.

YOHO: He sure did.

MCDOWELL: Why isn't that resonating with the voters? Why wouldn't he be leading Bill Nelson?

YOHO: Well, you know, I guess politics. You know, you've got all these negative ads going out there from both sides. Mainly, you see more attacks from the other side.

But then you look at, you know, where he stands on things. Rick Scott has not varied on who he is and what he said and what he said he was going to accomplish. He's done that. And the voters -- like I said, our internal polls show a different story than what you're seeing on national polls.

And then, you know, again I can account for District 3 which is six counties in north central Florida. But we talk to people all over the state. This economy that we have, we've not seen this before.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

YOHO: And then you take, you know, the tax cuts that we did with President Trump and rolled back regulations, that fits hand in hand. Andrew Gillum wants to go the other way --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

YOHO: -- and Bill Nelson want to go the other way. The people of Florida are not ready for that.

(CROSS TALKING)

BARTIROMO: And so you're just -- you're not believing -- you're not believing these polls. You say your polls say something different.

How important is the China story for Floridians? I mean the U.S.-China trade issue? The President yesterday sounded optimistic because he had a phone call with the Chinese President Xi Jinping.

But I spoke with the former CEO of Microsoft, Steve Ballmer yesterday, along with the chairman of IAC Barry Diller, and they were both incredibly concerned about China's business practices. Listen to this. I've got to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: 90 percent of companies are using the Microsoft operating platform and only 1 percent are paying for it. How do we -- what are we going to do that China keeps stealing everything this way? I mean that's pretty extraordinary.

STEVE BALLMER, FORMER CEO, MICROSOFT: I'm a free trader by nature. I went to school, economics -- it's the best thing for the world. This one's a tricky issue because it's absolutely clear that the rules don't apply in China and the U.S. government needs to do something -- whether tariffs are right or wrong, I'm silent on that point.

But without any pressure from the U.S. government, we're talking about $10 billion plus for example in Microsoft that would go into profit.

DILLER: Their trade practices have to change. And us being tough-minded about it, I think it's sensible. I think us being outrageous and excessive about it is dangerous. I don't think the trade war is -- if you let an unfettered trade war actually take place, which is in our control, it will be disastrous for everybody. So they will have to mature their practices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Congressman-- your reaction? Is this an issue for Floridians?

YOHO: It's an issue all over the nation. But what President Trump is doing is something that had to be done. Unchecked it would get worse. And so I'm glad he's doing what he's doing and I stand behind him.

BARTIROMO: Congressman -- it's good to have you on the program. We'll be watching the developments on Tuesday. It's nice (ph) to see you -- thank you.

YOHO: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Ted Yoho.

We also invited Congressman Yoho's opponent.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are watching earnings. We get two more Dow components coming this morning.

Cheryl Casone with all the details now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: A lot of market moving news before the market even opens -- Maria.

ExxonMobil expected to post double digit gains in earnings and revenue from a year ago with the average price for oil up 34 percent for the third quarter in general.

We're also going to get results from Chevron today. Analysts looking for the company's profits to double with revenue up nearly 30 percent. That's the oil story.

Alibaba out with its latest results just a few minutes ago. Revenue rising 54 percent from a year ago to $12.4 billion. Shares are substantially higher in the premarket, up almost 6 percent right now. All right. That stock though is off the highs from previous revenue guidance.

And also, we're looking at Apple, real quick here. The stock is trading sharply lower, down almost 6 percent in the premarket. Earnings, as we've been talking about today topped the street's estimates in the latest quarter but Apple also issued disappointing guidance for the current quarter which includes, of course, the holiday season and we've been talking about the unit sales issue. This raises questions about weaker than expected demand for their more expensive new iPhones which we're not going to be getting numbers on anymore.

All right. There is this -- a group of Tesla shareholders wants to put tighter reins on CEO Elon Musk. Three Tesla investors sent the board a letter saying the company should permanently separate the positions of chairman and chief executive, both of which Musk holds. That would go beyond Tesla's settlement with the SEC that required Musk to step down as chairman for just three years.

The directors are also calling for more turnover on the company's board, recommending a time line be set for some directors to leave. There is Tesla in the premarket, up almost three-quarters of a percent.

And then there is this -- bottomless beer no more. Co-working space Wework is now setting a limit for what used to be bottomless kegs of beer for its tenants. The New York tenants are now going to be limited to just four beers per day-- each person per day. Wework says that the change was determined by software to help manage the beer supply.

So it's a software issue, not the fact that people were getting drunk at Wework while they were working there. Ok.

BARTIROMO: I don't even understand that. They were drinking more than four beers a day during the day?

CASONE: Yes. Bottomless beer, bottomless mimosas -- you know what happens. This is what the story is.

BARTIROMO: What's in your cup?

KELLY: Oh yes. This is definitely not gin. It's for sure water.

But I just wanted real quickly on the Alibaba side --

BARTIROMO: Yes. Thanks -- Cheryl.

KELLY: I accidentally said that they beat on the top line, miss on the bottom. It was the inverse. Alibaba missed on the top line, beat significantly on the bottom line. But the main takeaway is that they actually guided their revenue forecast down 4 percent to 6 percent going forward.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Look at this. Stock is still up -- Kevin.

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: It's up almost 6 percent even though it's a revenue miss. Thank you.

Coming up, a scare on the high seas to tell you about -- details on the terrifying moments that caused a cruise ship to tilt. That's coming up.

Then countdown to the midterms is on, we break down why the number one issue for voters apparently according to the polls is health care.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are only four days away from the midterm elections. In a recent Fox News poll, health care is the number one issue driving Americans to the voting booth. Joining us right now is Dr. Joseph Galati. He is the author of "Eating Yourself Sick".

Why do you think health care has become a top priority in our country is the number one issue here? Dr. Galati -- good to see you. Thanks for being here.

DR. JOSEPH GALATI, AUTHOR, "EATING YOURSELF SICK": Well -- thank you, Maria.

You know, health care is always a hot button topic. Our patients -- the ones that I'm dealing with in Texas come to me with all sorts of insurance problems. They're worried about pre-existing. They're worried about insurance companies not covering certain procedures or disorders that they have.

And so a day doesn't go by that patients are not sitting in my office, talking and complaining about their health care. How it's going to be solved, I don't know.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GALATI: It's really a big, behemoth problem.

BARTIROMO: So James -- lay out the issue for us in terms of pre-existing conditions.

FREEMAN: Yes. So the idea is you don't want to let people buy insurance on their way to the hospital. This would be the argument to say let's have an insurance market. If you are sick already, you don't need insurance. You need health care.

So you need a system that allows people to get the care they need but if you're going to have an insurance market, they have to be able to sell to healthy people, not just sick people and so that's the theory. Now, the President has said he doesn't want to change anything with pre-existing conditions. That wasn't changed obviously. The Republicans never rewrote Obamacare.

So it's kind of a phony issue in that way. But to me, I don't know if you're hearing from patients, this issue of the Medicare-for-all plan, which ends Medicare and ends private insurance, in other words, it ends all pre-existing coverage, every person in the United States this is the plan that most Democrats in the House have endorsed -- Bernie Sanders, a lot of the Senate candidates. It ends all coverage in the U.S. and creates a new government plan. What does that mean for patients?

GALATI: You know, when you read about this Medicare for all, it's very thin on details. It's very thin on whether administrative costs are going to go down, whether it's going to provide better health care. That is really unclear.

And unfortunately, whenever people hear something for all, people jump on the bandwagon and say this is good for America. When really if we're voting on it or talking about it, the details are thin and you know, what really are we dealing with?

FREEMAN: But we do know from the legislation whether it's the Bernie Sanders plan or the one that most House Democrats have co-sponsored, it explicitly says private insurance goes away. Medicare goes away.

So this is the end of pre-existing coverage. Not just particular conditions. Your whole health plan is changing.

BARTIROMO: People do not understand this.

FREEMAN: I don't know why this isn't an issue in this election.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. And you're all about wellness and prevention, I mean getting ahead of disease.

GALATI: It is. And the sad part is, in my area of liver disease that I take care of, we see patients, we counsel them on staying well. Because taking care of somebody at the end is not the way to take care of yourself.

And so in the book, "Eating Yourself Sick", 30 years of interviewing thousands of patients, I see that. I had a conversation with a patient five years ago, six years ago, and they just continued to decline. And the common thread in so many of these diseases -- fatty liver disease, cirrhosis, diabetes, heart disease, cancer -- it's what we're eating.

It sounds real simple but what Americans are eating -- the processed foods -- is crazy. We have lost our way on eating at home, cooking at home with your children. And what I propose, as simple as it is, is to get back to the basics.

BARTIROMO: You're right. It's prevention all the way. Get ahead of disease. That will eliminate all the costs that we're faced with in the terms of cure and care rather than prevention.

GALATI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Dr. Galati -- we could talk about this all day.

GALATI: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: This is probably our favorite subject, actually.

GALATI: It is.

BARTIROMO: Thank you for joining us.

GALATI: Absolutely. It's been a pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you. Joseph Galati there.

Coming up -- the streaming wars are heating up, technology giants Amazon and (AUDIO GAP) Netflix.

Stay with us for part two of my exclusive interview with the chairman and senior exec of both IAC and Expedia Group. Barry Diller weighs in on big tech.

Stay with us.

730

urn:contentItem:5TNH-DVD1-JBHT-D16G-00000-00Apple Shares Slide; Florida Goes to the Polls; U.S. China Trade Tensions; Health Care is the Number One Issue for Voters2018-11-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisApple Shares Slide; Florida Goes to the Polls; U.S. China Trade Tensions; Health Care is the Number One Issue for VotersLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. TGIF.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Friday, November 2nd.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the button right now.

Major market moves this morning -- Apple shares the story of the day. It is down on weak revenue guidance and on the announcement that the company is no longer going to be providing unit sales. So we will not know specific unit sales on a quarterly basis anymore. The technology giant at risk of losing a $1-trillion market valuation with today's move. It is down 5.25 percent.

The other big story of the market, of course, is the October jobs report. Yes, it is jobs Friday right here. The expectation is for 190,000 jobs added to the economy in the month of October with the unemployment rate holding steady at 3.7 percent which is a multi-decade low.

We will take a look at what this means for the midterm elections and the market. Of course, the midterms now four days away.

Check out futures this morning. Even with the 5.5 percent selloff in Apple, we're looking at a rally of 260 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. It's going to be up about 1 percent right out of the gate this morning. The S&P 500 is expected to be up 21 points. That's three- quarters of 1 percent. And the Nasdaq right now up 15 points, a quarter of a percent on the Nasdaq.

This after another day of gains yesterday. This is the third day of gains for the markets yesterday. The Dow Industrials up 265 points at the close. All the major indices finished at their highs of the -- or near their highs of the session. The Dow, S&P up better than 1 percent; the Nasdaq up 1.75 percent, 128 points higher yesterday for the Nasdaq.

Markets this morning across the globe higher -- FT 100 up three-quarters of a percent, 53 points higher in London; one-and-a-third percent higher in Paris on the CAC 40 at 66 points higher; and the DAX index in Germany up 172 points, that's 1.5 percent higher in Germany.

In Asia, overnight gains across the board -- check it out. Best performer Hong Kong -- Hang Seng index up better than 4 percent overnight.

On the earnings front, we are watching Alibaba earnings later this morning. We will hear from oil giants and Dow components, ExxonMobil and Chevron. We'll have those numbers and analysis.

Right now, it's really Apple which is a big focus but these are coming out soon.

China trade in focus -- this was important yesterday in the markets. President Trump spoke with China's president Xi Jinping and apparently there was progress in the trade dispute from what we understand from that phone call. It definitely helped markets rally yesterday in the middle of the day.

Here's what IAC chairman Barry Diller told me about China's trade practices yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARRY DILLER, CHAIRMAN, IAC: I am not a proponent of quote, "trade wars" - - their trade practices have to change, trying to pick trade wars. If you let an unfettered trade war actually take place, which is in our control, it would be disastrous for everybody.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest coming up. More of Barry Diller this morning.

All those stories coming up this Friday morning. And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman; and Benchmark managing partner, Kevin Kelly. Great to see you this morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: So Alibaba is actually up right now 5 percent in the premarket because they actually beat pretty significantly on the revenues and on their bottom line. They have a revenue forecast cut on macroeconomic conditions though. So even though they did beat, so it was initially up 5 percent, now it seems like it's coming down a little bit because probably of this forecast of macro concerns.

And one of the things they're actually talking about is also the money they need to spend into their streaming services. So in order for them to be the Netflix of China, they're indicating they need to spend significantly more on their content.

BARTIROMO: So it is losing ground quickly.

KELLY: It is losing ground quickly. But they said their annual active buyers are actually up 23 percent so they're doing very well.

BARTIROMO: So the numbers are better than expected --

(CROSS TALKING)

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- but they're going to be having to see costs go up.

KELLY: Yes. They're seeing costs go up, and also they're guiding revenues down because of macro conditions. So unless Trump and President Xi Jinping have beautiful chocolate cake, Alibaba is very concerned.

BARTIROMO: The chocolate cake moment.

We've got a lot coming up this morning. Part two of my exclusive interview with the chairman and senior executive of both IAC and Expedia Group. That's Barry Diller. He weighs in on Amazon, Google, U.S. trade relations with China as well as General Electric as well. You don't want to miss a moment of it. So do stay with us for that interview.

But we want to get to Apple because the stock is trading down this morning on disappointing guidance. It is on track to shave about 85 points from the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Stock right now down 5.5 percent as CEO Tim Cook said that the company will no longer give unit sales figures in future reports. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: This is like if you go to the market and you push your cart up to the cashier and she says or he says how many units you have in there? It doesn't -- it doesn't matter a lot, how many units there are in there in terms of the overall value of what's in the cart.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Interesting. Well, I can understand the analogy. Does it not matter? I would imagine analysts --

KELLY: No. I think it matters.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: If your investors tell you it matters, then it matters. Whatever your messaging is -- more information is better. You can't be in the news business and say I want less information from the world's $1 trillion company.

BARTIROMO: Right.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": No, I'm not going to say that.

MCDOWELL: Ok.

FREEMAN: Obviously, you do want more information and as people think about the company's future, they want to see in each segment how it's doing. But I would say in his defense, this has never been a company that -- where it's about volume. Apple really has not been the big volume producer. That's the android universe.

So what Apple sells is to a smaller market but to a much more lucrative market, very high-priced, very high-margin products. So if you're seeing what you want to see on the revenue and the earnings from each of these products --

KELLY: I beg to differ.

(CROSS TALKING)

FREEMAN: I don't know that it's the end of the world that you don't see how many devices.

KELLY: It's not about that. It's not even about the iPhone anymore. It's 60 percent of sales now. It used to be a lot more of that. It actually used to be 75 percent of sales. But we need to get unit sales on Mac books, on their home pods, on their watches -- that is the next leg of growth for them and attribution into their ecosystem.

So the problem is that they missed on the services side. In order for the services side to grow, we need to know how many units they're selling of each product line. So I need to know what's in that shopping cart because they missed on the services.

They had less than $10 billion. They're saying that it's $10 billion. It was actually less than that. It was $9.981 billion when every analyst across the street had at least $10.18 billion.

MCDOWELL: We should point out that services --

(CROSS TALKING)

KELLY: So that's the biggest issue.

FREEMAN: The market agrees with you. Over time, I think this is probably not going to be --

BARTIROMO: You're calling this a miss.

KELLY: No -- but this is a miss. They missed on unit sales for iPhones which is 60 percent of the revenue. And then they're refreshing all their Macbook Pros and their watches and now we're not going to get guidance into that?

MCDOWELL: The growth -- they missed on the forecast for the December quarter that it was -- they show slowing growth there. That was the revenue forecast. In terms of the services business, we should just point out that's app store sales, Apple pay use, music streaming, subscriptions stuff like that -- revenue growth there was up 17 percent. That's slower in recent quarters.

When you have a valuation like this, you have to -- your growth rates need to be bigger and bigger and bigger, not smaller and smaller and smaller.

KELLY: That's it. And listen Morgan Stanley just downgraded the price target from $247 to $226 and their analyst has been very good on the stock. You had BAML -- Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch downgrade their price target to $223 --

BARTIROMO: Don't forget what Dan Miles -- I know I keep saying this -- but he was right. I mean what's your take on inventory because Dan said that in the second quarter inventory was up 89 percent. And that also goes hand in hand with the unit sales because if you've got all this inventory, first you've got get rid of that before you actually start producing more.

KELLY: That's it. And they're not expecting to sell more that's why you're seeing them increase the price of their products -- ok.

BARTIROMO: Right.

KELLY: And then they also had their component costs go down. So that's great. But I don't invest in the stock market looking in the rearview mirror. I invest looking forward.

BARTIROMO: Let's look forward to the jobs report. That's another major story this morning because the jobs report is coming out in an hour-and-a- half.

We want to check out one of the election's most pivotal states this morning and that's Florida.

Kristina Partsinevelos as has more from the Sunshine State this morning. And Kristina -- it's been a good jobs market in Florida as well. Good morning to you.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning. And you're right.

Yes, it is a pivotal race. It's a swing state. And this year is no different. We have a lot of people looking at the governor's race and the senate race.

We have former President Obama who is going to be here in Miami where I am right now on Route 1. It's very early in the morning so it's still quite dark out. He's throwing his support behind the Dems. You've got Andrew Gillum who's running for governor and then incumbent Bill Nelson who is also going for Senate. So those are the two candidates that former President Obama is supporting.

If we take a look at the Real Clear Politics polls and average multi-polls (ph) that we're seeing across the board for governor in Florida, you're seeing a slight lead, a little bit less than 3 percent for Gillum. Gillum is 39 years old, a progressive, mayor of Tallahassee -- pretty much pushing for higher minimum wage and higher corporate taxes.

He is going against Republican Ron DeSantis who has the full support of President Trump. They will be together on Saturday in Pensacola. And you have Ron DeSantis who is an advocate for gun control. There hasn't been a Democrat who's been elected for the governor's race since 1994.

And we switch over to Senate race which is also closely watched -- we look at the polls over there from Real Clear Politics again, you're seeing as of this morning less than 2 percent lead for Bill Nelson. So Bill Nelson, 75 years old, a centrist -- he's pushing for a ban on assault rifles.

And he's going against Governor Rick Scott who's very familiar here because he served two terms as governor. He wants to continue his political life which is why he's running for Senate. A lot can happen here.

We have former President Obama here, in Georgia on Friday and in Chicago on Sunday. Lots of movement in Florida and we're going to be here.

Back to you -- guys.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's really an important race. Kristina -- thank you. We'll keep checking back. Kristina Partsinevelos is in Miami this morning.

Joining us right now is Florida Congressman Ted Yoho. He's running for office in Florida's third congressional district and is on the Foreign Affairs and Agriculture House Committees. Sir -- it's good to have you on this morning.

REP. TED YOHO (R), FLORIDA: Hi.

BARTIROMO: Thanks very much for joining us.

YOHO: Good morning -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: How do you feel going into the midterms in terms of your own prospects?

YOHO: I feel really good. We've got a lot of momentum on the ground. We've got people out door-knocking, making phone calls. We're doing rallies and coffees all over the district.

The momentum is on our side that we're seeing. And I think you're going to see it carry through the governor's race and the Senate race with Rick Scott.

BARTIROMO: Well, it doesn't look like that. We're looking at the numbers. And if you believe the polls, it looks like Gillum is in the lead and even Nelson is in the lead. What do you think about that?

YOHO: Well, we got internal polls-- we've got internal polls that show different. If you go back to the last presidential election, they had Hillary Clinton leading the day of the election. So I think there's a lot of movement on the ground. I think you're going see this.

And then you've got our governor's race -- you know, you've got a guy that's under FBI investigation and he's got a liberal progressive agenda that wants to roll back what Rick Scott has done.

And then you compare Rick Scott's record with Bill Nelson is just like a place holder and he's not accomplished a whole lot. Rick Scott has created 1.6 million jobs in this state, lowered taxes and we've got one of the best ratings, if not the best rating in the country for a state.

Rick Scott has done an awesome job. He'll do that in the senate. And I can't wait for him to get up there and work with him.

MCDOWELL: Congressman -- it's Dagen McDowell. The unemployment rate in the state of Florida is below the national average. It was 3.5 percent in Florida.

YOHO: It sure is.

MCDOWELL: Rick Scott took that economy to a trillion dollars in terms of its value.

YOHO: He sure did.

MCDOWELL: Why isn't that resonating with the voters? Why wouldn't he be leading Bill Nelson?

YOHO: Well, you know, I guess politics. You know, you've got all these negative ads going out there from both sides. Mainly, you see more attacks from the other side.

But then you look at, you know, where he stands on things. Rick Scott has not varied on who he is and what he said and what he said he was going to accomplish. He's done that. And the voters -- like I said, our internal polls show a different story than what you're seeing on national polls.

And then, you know, again I can account for District 3 which is six counties in north central Florida. But we talk to people all over the state. This economy that we have, we've not seen this before.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

YOHO: And then you take, you know, the tax cuts that we did with President Trump and rolled back regulations, that fits hand in hand. Andrew Gillum wants to go the other way --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

YOHO: -- and Bill Nelson want to go the other way. The people of Florida are not ready for that.

(CROSS TALKING)

BARTIROMO: And so you're just -- you're not believing -- you're not believing these polls. You say your polls say something different.

How important is the China story for Floridians? I mean the U.S.-China trade issue? The President yesterday sounded optimistic because he had a phone call with the Chinese President Xi Jinping.

But I spoke with the former CEO of Microsoft, Steve Ballmer yesterday, along with the chairman of IAC Barry Diller, and they were both incredibly concerned about China's business practices. Listen to this. I've got to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: 90 percent of companies are using the Microsoft operating platform and only 1 percent are paying for it. How do we -- what are we going to do that China keeps stealing everything this way? I mean that's pretty extraordinary.

STEVE BALLMER, FORMER CEO, MICROSOFT: I'm a free trader by nature. I went to school, economics -- it's the best thing for the world. This one's a tricky issue because it's absolutely clear that the rules don't apply in China and the U.S. government needs to do something -- whether tariffs are right or wrong, I'm silent on that point.

But without any pressure from the U.S. government, we're talking about $10 billion plus for example in Microsoft that would go into profit.

DILLER: Their trade practices have to change. And us being tough-minded about it, I think it's sensible. I think us being outrageous and excessive about it is dangerous. I don't think the trade war is -- if you let an unfettered trade war actually take place, which is in our control, it will be disastrous for everybody. So they will have to mature their practices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Congressman-- your reaction? Is this an issue for Floridians?

YOHO: It's an issue all over the nation. But what President Trump is doing is something that had to be done. Unchecked it would get worse. And so I'm glad he's doing what he's doing and I stand behind him.

BARTIROMO: Congressman -- it's good to have you on the program. We'll be watching the developments on Tuesday. It's nice (ph) to see you -- thank you.

YOHO: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Ted Yoho.

We also invited Congressman Yoho's opponent.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are watching earnings. We get two more Dow components coming this morning.

Cheryl Casone with all the details now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: A lot of market moving news before the market even opens -- Maria.

ExxonMobil expected to post double digit gains in earnings and revenue from a year ago with the average price for oil up 34 percent for the third quarter in general.

We're also going to get results from Chevron today. Analysts looking for the company's profits to double with revenue up nearly 30 percent. That's the oil story.

Alibaba out with its latest results just a few minutes ago. Revenue rising 54 percent from a year ago to $12.4 billion. Shares are substantially higher in the premarket, up almost 6 percent right now. All right. That stock though is off the highs from previous revenue guidance.

And also, we're looking at Apple, real quick here. The stock is trading sharply lower, down almost 6 percent in the premarket. Earnings, as we've been talking about today topped the street's estimates in the latest quarter but Apple also issued disappointing guidance for the current quarter which includes, of course, the holiday season and we've been talking about the unit sales issue. This raises questions about weaker than expected demand for their more expensive new iPhones which we're not going to be getting numbers on anymore.

All right. There is this -- a group of Tesla shareholders wants to put tighter reins on CEO Elon Musk. Three Tesla investors sent the board a letter saying the company should permanently separate the positions of chairman and chief executive, both of which Musk holds. That would go beyond Tesla's settlement with the SEC that required Musk to step down as chairman for just three years.

The directors are also calling for more turnover on the company's board, recommending a time line be set for some directors to leave. There is Tesla in the premarket, up almost three-quarters of a percent.

And then there is this -- bottomless beer no more. Co-working space Wework is now setting a limit for what used to be bottomless kegs of beer for its tenants. The New York tenants are now going to be limited to just four beers per day-- each person per day. Wework says that the change was determined by software to help manage the beer supply.

So it's a software issue, not the fact that people were getting drunk at Wework while they were working there. Ok.

BARTIROMO: I don't even understand that. They were drinking more than four beers a day during the day?

CASONE: Yes. Bottomless beer, bottomless mimosas -- you know what happens. This is what the story is.

BARTIROMO: What's in your cup?

KELLY: Oh yes. This is definitely not gin. It's for sure water.

But I just wanted real quickly on the Alibaba side --

BARTIROMO: Yes. Thanks -- Cheryl.

KELLY: I accidentally said that they beat on the top line, miss on the bottom. It was the inverse. Alibaba missed on the top line, beat significantly on the bottom line. But the main takeaway is that they actually guided their revenue forecast down 4 percent to 6 percent going forward.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Look at this. Stock is still up -- Kevin.

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: It's up almost 6 percent even though it's a revenue miss. Thank you.

Coming up, a scare on the high seas to tell you about -- details on the terrifying moments that caused a cruise ship to tilt. That's coming up.

Then countdown to the midterms is on, we break down why the number one issue for voters apparently according to the polls is health care.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are only four days away from the midterm elections. In a recent Fox News poll, health care is the number one issue driving Americans to the voting booth. Joining us right now is Dr. Joseph Galati. He is the author of "Eating Yourself Sick".

Why do you think health care has become a top priority in our country is the number one issue here? Dr. Galati -- good to see you. Thanks for being here.

DR. JOSEPH GALATI, AUTHOR, "EATING YOURSELF SICK": Well -- thank you, Maria.

You know, health care is always a hot button topic. Our patients -- the ones that I'm dealing with in Texas come to me with all sorts of insurance problems. They're worried about pre-existing. They're worried about insurance companies not covering certain procedures or disorders that they have.

And so a day doesn't go by that patients are not sitting in my office, talking and complaining about their health care. How it's going to be solved, I don't know.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GALATI: It's really a big, behemoth problem.

BARTIROMO: So James -- lay out the issue for us in terms of pre-existing conditions.

FREEMAN: Yes. So the idea is you don't want to let people buy insurance on their way to the hospital. This would be the argument to say let's have an insurance market. If you are sick already, you don't need insurance. You need health care.

So you need a system that allows people to get the care they need but if you're going to have an insurance market, they have to be able to sell to healthy people, not just sick people and so that's the theory. Now, the President has said he doesn't want to change anything with pre-existing conditions. That wasn't changed obviously. The Republicans never rewrote Obamacare.

So it's kind of a phony issue in that way. But to me, I don't know if you're hearing from patients, this issue of the Medicare-for-all plan, which ends Medicare and ends private insurance, in other words, it ends all pre-existing coverage, every person in the United States this is the plan that most Democrats in the House have endorsed -- Bernie Sanders, a lot of the Senate candidates. It ends all coverage in the U.S. and creates a new government plan. What does that mean for patients?

GALATI: You know, when you read about this Medicare for all, it's very thin on details. It's very thin on whether administrative costs are going to go down, whether it's going to provide better health care. That is really unclear.

And unfortunately, whenever people hear something for all, people jump on the bandwagon and say this is good for America. When really if we're voting on it or talking about it, the details are thin and you know, what really are we dealing with?

FREEMAN: But we do know from the legislation whether it's the Bernie Sanders plan or the one that most House Democrats have co-sponsored, it explicitly says private insurance goes away. Medicare goes away.

So this is the end of pre-existing coverage. Not just particular conditions. Your whole health plan is changing.

BARTIROMO: People do not understand this.

FREEMAN: I don't know why this isn't an issue in this election.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. And you're all about wellness and prevention, I mean getting ahead of disease.

GALATI: It is. And the sad part is, in my area of liver disease that I take care of, we see patients, we counsel them on staying well. Because taking care of somebody at the end is not the way to take care of yourself.

And so in the book, "Eating Yourself Sick", 30 years of interviewing thousands of patients, I see that. I had a conversation with a patient five years ago, six years ago, and they just continued to decline. And the common thread in so many of these diseases -- fatty liver disease, cirrhosis, diabetes, heart disease, cancer -- it's what we're eating.

It sounds real simple but what Americans are eating -- the processed foods -- is crazy. We have lost our way on eating at home, cooking at home with your children. And what I propose, as simple as it is, is to get back to the basics.

BARTIROMO: You're right. It's prevention all the way. Get ahead of disease. That will eliminate all the costs that we're faced with in the terms of cure and care rather than prevention.

GALATI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Dr. Galati -- we could talk about this all day.

GALATI: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: This is probably our favorite subject, actually.

GALATI: It is.

BARTIROMO: Thank you for joining us.

GALATI: Absolutely. It's been a pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you. Joseph Galati there.

Coming up -- the streaming wars are heating up, technology giants Amazon and (AUDIO GAP) Netflix.

Stay with us for part two of my exclusive interview with the chairman and senior exec of both IAC and Expedia Group. Barry Diller weighs in on big tech.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

730

END

urn:contentItem:5TNH-DVD1-JBHT-D15X-00000-00Apple Shares Slide; Florida Goes to the Polls; U.S. China Trade Tensions; Health Care is the Number One Issue for Voters2018-11-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisApple Shares Slide; Florida Goes to the Polls; U.S. China Trade Tensions; Health Care is the Number One Issue for VotersLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. TGIF.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Friday, November 2nd.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the button right now.

Major market moves this morning -- Apple shares the story of the day. It is down on weak revenue guidance and on the announcement that the company is no longer going to be providing unit sales. So we will not know specific unit sales on a quarterly basis anymore. The technology giant at risk of losing a $1-trillion market valuation with today's move. It is down 5.25 percent.

The other big story of the market, of course, is the October jobs report. Yes, it is jobs Friday right here. The expectation is for 190,000 jobs added to the economy in the month of October with the unemployment rate holding steady at 3.7 percent which is a multi-decade low.

We will take a look at what this means for the midterm elections and the market. Of course, the midterms now four days away.

Check out futures this morning. Even with the 5.5 percent selloff in Apple, we're looking at a rally of 260 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. It's going to be up about 1 percent right out of the gate this morning. The S&P 500 is expected to be up 21 points. That's three- quarters of 1 percent. And the Nasdaq right now up 15 points, a quarter of a percent on the Nasdaq.

This after another day of gains yesterday. This is the third day of gains for the markets yesterday. The Dow Industrials up 265 points at the close. All the major indices finished at their highs of the -- or near their highs of the session. The Dow, S&P up better than 1 percent; the Nasdaq up 1.75 percent, 128 points higher yesterday for the Nasdaq.

Markets this morning across the globe higher -- FT 100 up three-quarters of a percent, 53 points higher in London; one-and-a-third percent higher in Paris on the CAC 40 at 66 points higher; and the DAX index in Germany up 172 points, that's 1.5 percent higher in Germany.

In Asia, overnight gains across the board -- check it out. Best performer Hong Kong -- Hang Seng index up better than 4 percent overnight.

On the earnings front, we are watching Alibaba earnings later this morning. We will hear from oil giants and Dow components, ExxonMobil and Chevron. We'll have those numbers and analysis.

Right now, it's really Apple which is a big focus but these are coming out soon.

China trade in focus -- this was important yesterday in the markets. President Trump spoke with China's president Xi Jinping and apparently there was progress in the trade dispute from what we understand from that phone call. It definitely helped markets rally yesterday in the middle of the day.

Here's what IAC chairman Barry Diller told me about China's trade practices yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARRY DILLER, CHAIRMAN, IAC: I am not a proponent of quote, "trade wars" - - their trade practices have to change, trying to pick trade wars. If you let an unfettered trade war actually take place, which is in our control, it would be disastrous for everybody.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest coming up. More of Barry Diller this morning.

All those stories coming up this Friday morning. And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman; and Benchmark managing partner, Kevin Kelly. Great to see you this morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: So Alibaba is actually up right now 5 percent in the premarket because they actually beat pretty significantly on the revenues and on their bottom line. They have a revenue forecast cut on macroeconomic conditions though. So even though they did beat, so it was initially up 5 percent, now it seems like it's coming down a little bit because probably of this forecast of macro concerns.

And one of the things they're actually talking about is also the money they need to spend into their streaming services. So in order for them to be the Netflix of China, they're indicating they need to spend significantly more on their content.

BARTIROMO: So it is losing ground quickly.

KELLY: It is losing ground quickly. But they said their annual active buyers are actually up 23 percent so they're doing very well.

BARTIROMO: So the numbers are better than expected --

(CROSS TALKING)

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- but they're going to be having to see costs go up.

KELLY: Yes. They're seeing costs go up, and also they're guiding revenues down because of macro conditions. So unless Trump and President Xi Jinping have beautiful chocolate cake, Alibaba is very concerned.

BARTIROMO: The chocolate cake moment.

We've got a lot coming up this morning. Part two of my exclusive interview with the chairman and senior executive of both IAC and Expedia Group. That's Barry Diller. He weighs in on Amazon, Google, U.S. trade relations with China as well as General Electric as well. You don't want to miss a moment of it. So do stay with us for that interview.

But we want to get to Apple because the stock is trading down this morning on disappointing guidance. It is on track to shave about 85 points from the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Stock right now down 5.5 percent as CEO Tim Cook said that the company will no longer give unit sales figures in future reports. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: This is like if you go to the market and you push your cart up to the cashier and she says or he says how many units you have in there? It doesn't -- it doesn't matter a lot, how many units there are in there in terms of the overall value of what's in the cart.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Interesting. Well, I can understand the analogy. Does it not matter? I would imagine analysts --

KELLY: No. I think it matters.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: If your investors tell you it matters, then it matters. Whatever your messaging is -- more information is better. You can't be in the news business and say I want less information from the world's $1 trillion company.

BARTIROMO: Right.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": No, I'm not going to say that.

MCDOWELL: Ok.

FREEMAN: Obviously, you do want more information and as people think about the company's future, they want to see in each segment how it's doing. But I would say in his defense, this has never been a company that -- where it's about volume. Apple really has not been the big volume producer. That's the android universe.

So what Apple sells is to a smaller market but to a much more lucrative market, very high-priced, very high-margin products. So if you're seeing what you want to see on the revenue and the earnings from each of these products --

KELLY: I beg to differ.

(CROSS TALKING)

FREEMAN: I don't know that it's the end of the world that you don't see how many devices.

KELLY: It's not about that. It's not even about the iPhone anymore. It's 60 percent of sales now. It used to be a lot more of that. It actually used to be 75 percent of sales. But we need to get unit sales on Mac books, on their home pods, on their watches -- that is the next leg of growth for them and attribution into their ecosystem.

So the problem is that they missed on the services side. In order for the services side to grow, we need to know how many units they're selling of each product line. So I need to know what's in that shopping cart because they missed on the services.

They had less than $10 billion. They're saying that it's $10 billion. It was actually less than that. It was $9.981 billion when every analyst across the street had at least $10.18 billion.

MCDOWELL: We should point out that services --

(CROSS TALKING)

KELLY: So that's the biggest issue.

FREEMAN: The market agrees with you. Over time, I think this is probably not going to be --

BARTIROMO: You're calling this a miss.

KELLY: No -- but this is a miss. They missed on unit sales for iPhones which is 60 percent of the revenue. And then they're refreshing all their Macbook Pros and their watches and now we're not going to get guidance into that?

MCDOWELL: The growth -- they missed on the forecast for the December quarter that it was -- they show slowing growth there. That was the revenue forecast. In terms of the services business, we should just point out that's app store sales, Apple pay use, music streaming, subscriptions stuff like that -- revenue growth there was up 17 percent. That's slower in recent quarters.

When you have a valuation like this, you have to -- your growth rates need to be bigger and bigger and bigger, not smaller and smaller and smaller.

KELLY: That's it. And listen Morgan Stanley just downgraded the price target from $247 to $226 and their analyst has been very good on the stock. You had BAML -- Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch downgrade their price target to $223 --

BARTIROMO: Don't forget what Dan Miles -- I know I keep saying this -- but he was right. I mean what's your take on inventory because Dan said that in the second quarter inventory was up 89 percent. And that also goes hand in hand with the unit sales because if you've got all this inventory, first you've got get rid of that before you actually start producing more.

KELLY: That's it. And they're not expecting to sell more that's why you're seeing them increase the price of their products -- ok.

BARTIROMO: Right.

KELLY: And then they also had their component costs go down. So that's great. But I don't invest in the stock market looking in the rearview mirror. I invest looking forward.

BARTIROMO: Let's look forward to the jobs report. That's another major story this morning because the jobs report is coming out in an hour-and-a- half.

We want to check out one of the election's most pivotal states this morning and that's Florida.

Kristina Partsinevelos as has more from the Sunshine State this morning. And Kristina -- it's been a good jobs market in Florida as well. Good morning to you.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning. And you're right.

Yes, it is a pivotal race. It's a swing state. And this year is no different. We have a lot of people looking at the governor's race and the senate race.

We have former President Obama who is going to be here in Miami where I am right now on Route 1. It's very early in the morning so it's still quite dark out. He's throwing his support behind the Dems. You've got Andrew Gillum who's running for governor and then incumbent Bill Nelson who is also going for Senate. So those are the two candidates that former President Obama is supporting.

If we take a look at the Real Clear Politics polls and average multi-polls (ph) that we're seeing across the board for governor in Florida, you're seeing a slight lead, a little bit less than 3 percent for Gillum. Gillum is 39 years old, a progressive, mayor of Tallahassee -- pretty much pushing for higher minimum wage and higher corporate taxes.

He is going against Republican Ron DeSantis who has the full support of President Trump. They will be together on Saturday in Pensacola. And you have Ron DeSantis who is an advocate for gun control. There hasn't been a Democrat who's been elected for the governor's race since 1994.

And we switch over to Senate race which is also closely watched -- we look at the polls over there from Real Clear Politics again, you're seeing as of this morning less than 2 percent lead for Bill Nelson. So Bill Nelson, 75 years old, a centrist -- he's pushing for a ban on assault rifles.

And he's going against Governor Rick Scott who's very familiar here because he served two terms as governor. He wants to continue his political life which is why he's running for Senate. A lot can happen here.

We have former President Obama here, in Georgia on Friday and in Chicago on Sunday. Lots of movement in Florida and we're going to be here.

Back to you -- guys.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's really an important race. Kristina -- thank you. We'll keep checking back. Kristina Partsinevelos is in Miami this morning.

Joining us right now is Florida Congressman Ted Yoho. He's running for office in Florida's third congressional district and is on the Foreign Affairs and Agriculture House Committees. Sir -- it's good to have you on this morning.

REP. TED YOHO (R), FLORIDA: Hi.

BARTIROMO: Thanks very much for joining us.

YOHO: Good morning -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: How do you feel going into the midterms in terms of your own prospects?

YOHO: I feel really good. We've got a lot of momentum on the ground. We've got people out door-knocking, making phone calls. We're doing rallies and coffees all over the district.

The momentum is on our side that we're seeing. And I think you're going to see it carry through the governor's race and the Senate race with Rick Scott.

BARTIROMO: Well, it doesn't look like that. We're looking at the numbers. And if you believe the polls, it looks like Gillum is in the lead and even Nelson is in the lead. What do you think about that?

YOHO: Well, we got internal polls-- we've got internal polls that show different. If you go back to the last presidential election, they had Hillary Clinton leading the day of the election. So I think there's a lot of movement on the ground. I think you're going see this.

And then you've got our governor's race -- you know, you've got a guy that's under FBI investigation and he's got a liberal progressive agenda that wants to roll back what Rick Scott has done.

And then you compare Rick Scott's record with Bill Nelson is just like a place holder and he's not accomplished a whole lot. Rick Scott has created 1.6 million jobs in this state, lowered taxes and we've got one of the best ratings, if not the best rating in the country for a state.

Rick Scott has done an awesome job. He'll do that in the senate. And I can't wait for him to get up there and work with him.

MCDOWELL: Congressman -- it's Dagen McDowell. The unemployment rate in the state of Florida is below the national average. It was 3.5 percent in Florida.

YOHO: It sure is.

MCDOWELL: Rick Scott took that economy to a trillion dollars in terms of its value.

YOHO: He sure did.

MCDOWELL: Why isn't that resonating with the voters? Why wouldn't he be leading Bill Nelson?

YOHO: Well, you know, I guess politics. You know, you've got all these negative ads going out there from both sides. Mainly, you see more attacks from the other side.

But then you look at, you know, where he stands on things. Rick Scott has not varied on who he is and what he said and what he said he was going to accomplish. He's done that. And the voters -- like I said, our internal polls show a different story than what you're seeing on national polls.

And then, you know, again I can account for District 3 which is six counties in north central Florida. But we talk to people all over the state. This economy that we have, we've not seen this before.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

YOHO: And then you take, you know, the tax cuts that we did with President Trump and rolled back regulations, that fits hand in hand. Andrew Gillum wants to go the other way --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

YOHO: -- and Bill Nelson want to go the other way. The people of Florida are not ready for that.

(CROSS TALKING)

BARTIROMO: And so you're just -- you're not believing -- you're not believing these polls. You say your polls say something different.

How important is the China story for Floridians? I mean the U.S.-China trade issue? The President yesterday sounded optimistic because he had a phone call with the Chinese President Xi Jinping.

But I spoke with the former CEO of Microsoft, Steve Ballmer yesterday, along with the chairman of IAC Barry Diller, and they were both incredibly concerned about China's business practices. Listen to this. I've got to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: 90 percent of companies are using the Microsoft operating platform and only 1 percent are paying for it. How do we -- what are we going to do that China keeps stealing everything this way? I mean that's pretty extraordinary.

STEVE BALLMER, FORMER CEO, MICROSOFT: I'm a free trader by nature. I went to school, economics -- it's the best thing for the world. This one's a tricky issue because it's absolutely clear that the rules don't apply in China and the U.S. government needs to do something -- whether tariffs are right or wrong, I'm silent on that point.

But without any pressure from the U.S. government, we're talking about $10 billion plus for example in Microsoft that would go into profit.

DILLER: Their trade practices have to change. And us being tough-minded about it, I think it's sensible. I think us being outrageous and excessive about it is dangerous. I don't think the trade war is -- if you let an unfettered trade war actually take place, which is in our control, it will be disastrous for everybody. So they will have to mature their practices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Congressman-- your reaction? Is this an issue for Floridians?

YOHO: It's an issue all over the nation. But what President Trump is doing is something that had to be done. Unchecked it would get worse. And so I'm glad he's doing what he's doing and I stand behind him.

BARTIROMO: Congressman -- it's good to have you on the program. We'll be watching the developments on Tuesday. It's nice (ph) to see you -- thank you.

YOHO: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Ted Yoho.

We also invited Congressman Yoho's opponent.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are watching earnings. We get two more Dow components coming this morning.

Cheryl Casone with all the details now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: A lot of market moving news before the market even opens -- Maria.

ExxonMobil expected to post double digit gains in earnings and revenue from a year ago with the average price for oil up 34 percent for the third quarter in general.

We're also going to get results from Chevron today. Analysts looking for the company's profits to double with revenue up nearly 30 percent. That's the oil story.

Alibaba out with its latest results just a few minutes ago. Revenue rising 54 percent from a year ago to $12.4 billion. Shares are substantially higher in the premarket, up almost 6 percent right now. All right. That stock though is off the highs from previous revenue guidance.

And also, we're looking at Apple, real quick here. The stock is trading sharply lower, down almost 6 percent in the premarket. Earnings, as we've been talking about today topped the street's estimates in the latest quarter but Apple also issued disappointing guidance for the current quarter which includes, of course, the holiday season and we've been talking about the unit sales issue. This raises questions about weaker than expected demand for their more expensive new iPhones which we're not going to be getting numbers on anymore.

All right. There is this -- a group of Tesla shareholders wants to put tighter reins on CEO Elon Musk. Three Tesla investors sent the board a letter saying the company should permanently separate the positions of chairman and chief executive, both of which Musk holds. That would go beyond Tesla's settlement with the SEC that required Musk to step down as chairman for just three years.

The directors are also calling for more turnover on the company's board, recommending a time line be set for some directors to leave. There is Tesla in the premarket, up almost three-quarters of a percent.

And then there is this -- bottomless beer no more. Co-working space Wework is now setting a limit for what used to be bottomless kegs of beer for its tenants. The New York tenants are now going to be limited to just four beers per day-- each person per day. Wework says that the change was determined by software to help manage the beer supply.

So it's a software issue, not the fact that people were getting drunk at Wework while they were working there. Ok.

BARTIROMO: I don't even understand that. They were drinking more than four beers a day during the day?

CASONE: Yes. Bottomless beer, bottomless mimosas -- you know what happens. This is what the story is.

BARTIROMO: What's in your cup?

KELLY: Oh yes. This is definitely not gin. It's for sure water.

But I just wanted real quickly on the Alibaba side --

BARTIROMO: Yes. Thanks -- Cheryl.

KELLY: I accidentally said that they beat on the top line, miss on the bottom. It was the inverse. Alibaba missed on the top line, beat significantly on the bottom line. But the main takeaway is that they actually guided their revenue forecast down 4 percent to 6 percent going forward.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Look at this. Stock is still up -- Kevin.

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: It's up almost 6 percent even though it's a revenue miss. Thank you.

Coming up, a scare on the high seas to tell you about -- details on the terrifying moments that caused a cruise ship to tilt. That's coming up.

Then countdown to the midterms is on, we break down why the number one issue for voters apparently according to the polls is health care.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are only four days away from the midterm elections. In a recent Fox News poll, health care is the number one issue driving Americans to the voting booth. Joining us right now is Dr. Joseph Galati. He is the author of "Eating Yourself Sick".

Why do you think health care has become a top priority in our country is the number one issue here? Dr. Galati -- good to see you. Thanks for being here.

DR. JOSEPH GALATI, AUTHOR, "EATING YOURSELF SICK": Well -- thank you, Maria.

You know, health care is always a hot button topic. Our patients -- the ones that I'm dealing with in Texas come to me with all sorts of insurance problems. They're worried about pre-existing. They're worried about insurance companies not covering certain procedures or disorders that they have.

And so a day doesn't go by that patients are not sitting in my office, talking and complaining about their health care. How it's going to be solved, I don't know.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GALATI: It's really a big, behemoth problem.

BARTIROMO: So James -- lay out the issue for us in terms of pre-existing conditions.

FREEMAN: Yes. So the idea is you don't want to let people buy insurance on their way to the hospital. This would be the argument to say let's have an insurance market. If you are sick already, you don't need insurance. You need health care.

So you need a system that allows people to get the care they need but if you're going to have an insurance market, they have to be able to sell to healthy people, not just sick people and so that's the theory. Now, the President has said he doesn't want to change anything with pre-existing conditions. That wasn't changed obviously. The Republicans never rewrote Obamacare.

So it's kind of a phony issue in that way. But to me, I don't know if you're hearing from patients, this issue of the Medicare-for-all plan, which ends Medicare and ends private insurance, in other words, it ends all pre-existing coverage, every person in the United States this is the plan that most Democrats in the House have endorsed -- Bernie Sanders, a lot of the Senate candidates. It ends all coverage in the U.S. and creates a new government plan. What does that mean for patients?

GALATI: You know, when you read about this Medicare for all, it's very thin on details. It's very thin on whether administrative costs are going to go down, whether it's going to provide better health care. That is really unclear.

And unfortunately, whenever people hear something for all, people jump on the bandwagon and say this is good for America. When really if we're voting on it or talking about it, the details are thin and you know, what really are we dealing with?

FREEMAN: But we do know from the legislation whether it's the Bernie Sanders plan or the one that most House Democrats have co-sponsored, it explicitly says private insurance goes away. Medicare goes away.

So this is the end of pre-existing coverage. Not just particular conditions. Your whole health plan is changing.

BARTIROMO: People do not understand this.

FREEMAN: I don't know why this isn't an issue in this election.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. And you're all about wellness and prevention, I mean getting ahead of disease.

GALATI: It is. And the sad part is, in my area of liver disease that I take care of, we see patients, we counsel them on staying well. Because taking care of somebody at the end is not the way to take care of yourself.

And so in the book, "Eating Yourself Sick", 30 years of interviewing thousands of patients, I see that. I had a conversation with a patient five years ago, six years ago, and they just continued to decline. And the common thread in so many of these diseases -- fatty liver disease, cirrhosis, diabetes, heart disease, cancer -- it's what we're eating.

It sounds real simple but what Americans are eating -- the processed foods -- is crazy. We have lost our way on eating at home, cooking at home with your children. And what I propose, as simple as it is, is to get back to the basics.

BARTIROMO: You're right. It's prevention all the way. Get ahead of disease. That will eliminate all the costs that we're faced with in the terms of cure and care rather than prevention.

GALATI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Dr. Galati -- we could talk about this all day.

GALATI: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: This is probably our favorite subject, actually.

GALATI: It is.

BARTIROMO: Thank you for joining us.

GALATI: Absolutely. It's been a pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you. Joseph Galati there.

Coming up -- the streaming wars are heating up, technology giants Amazon and (AUDIO GAP) Netflix.

Stay with us for part two of my exclusive interview with the chairman and senior exec of both IAC and Expedia Group. Barry Diller weighs in on big tech.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

730

END
