The automaker had planned to shutdown that plant three-shift consolidated line next June, but will operate with at least one line until June of 2014. The CAW continues to negotiate a deal with Chrysler after it already reached one with Ford earlier in the week.

IMUS IN THE MORNING continues now after we check the weather with Fox 5 meteorologist, Mike Woods.

MIKE WOODS, FOX 5 METEOROLOGIST: Good morning, everyone. Looks like we have some wet weather out there, but not a ton of it for the country here. We've got an area of low pressure still rotating around the Great Lakes, but it's bringing showers from the Upper Midwest and Central Mississippi Valley area.

And then back towards the rest of the Great Lakes over to the east and also a few showers popping up around Florida again, southeast, slightly risky in terms of showers and storms. Tampa, you'll see a few scattered storms and high temp today, 88 degrees.

And Phoenix, no rain for you, sunny skies with a high of 103 and Seattle partly cloudy skies with a high of 63. Sacramento, California, you've got sunny skies there today with a high of 91, still warm. I'm Mike Woods from Fox 5 in New York.

IMUS: All right, it's 36 minutes past the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Please welcome to the program, senior vice president, anchor manager, Fox Business News, Fox News Channel, a man who sadly calls himself the financial factor, Neil P. Cavuto. What does the P stand for?

NEIL P. CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS: Patrick.

IMUS: Good morning, Mr. Cavuto.

CAVUTO: Good morning, Mr. Imus.

IMUS: How are you?

CAVUTO: It was scary bumping into you this morning.

IMUS: Well, I had my little oxygen tank with me.

CAVUTO: You kind of looked like Hannibal Lector being driven in on a gurney and I thought, is he up to doing the show today? But here you are, encouragement to all us.

IMUS: Well, anaerobic, but I recover quickly and I don't need oxygen just to sit around and talk.

CAVUTO: I admire that.

IMUS: Happy birthday tomorrow.

CAVUTO: How did you know that?

IMUS: It's my job to know those things.

CAVUTO: Thank you very much.

IMUS: So, you like the Vince Gill interview?

CAVUTO: I liked it very much, I'm a big fan of his and I thought you did a very good job. A lot of people, you know, when you interview stars it's always tough. You do a fawning interview or you do a revealing one particularly like the things about your brother, how tough that is and trying to get a handle on it, very real. I liked it very much.

IMUS: So I asked you off the air if you liked Romney. Do you?

CAVUTO: I do, personally I like him a lot.

IMUS: It doesn't bother you that he's a dope, right?

CAVUTO: He's not a dope.

IMUS: OK, he's not a good campaigner, is he?

CAVUTO: I think that remains to be seen. The election hasn't happened yet.

IMUS: No, sir. Do you think that these leaked videos, these missteps that they've each made, is going to make a difference when people vote?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: You don't?

CAVUTO: I do not. I think in the end, it always is the economy. I think that's what-- we could have extenuating circumstances, the Middle East explosion, could have the impact, but almost every U.S. election is decided by the economy.

How good people feel, how maybe not so good people feel and we're always willing to entertain switching horses mid stream when an incumbent is battling a tough economy, but we've really got to see the other horse.

I think in 1980 when the polls were similarly tight between Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. A lot of people liked Jimmy Carter, frustrated with the economy, but they were more than willing to entertain an alternative and along came Ronald Reagan to appeal to alternative.

IMUS: How many people vote for the person who they like the best?

CAVUTO: I think it plays a part.

IMUS: How big a part?

CAVUTO: Well, I do think it helped George Bush, many polls were done on the debate between he and Al Gore and then later on between he and John Kerry. And I think most people said who won the debates?

And a lot of them said, particularly in 2004, with John Kerry, who do you like more or relate to more? George Bush. I'm not saying that's always the case, but it does help if people feel you're either more approachable or likeable.

And I think in 1960 from the television critics later who said that Richard Nixon was sweating and detached and John Kennedy looked relaxed and smooth. These things on some level do connect for people.

IMUS: Talking with Neil Cavuto -- talking with Neil Cavuto here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. It's 5 until the hour, you know what you ought to do here at Fox?

CAVUTO: What's that?

IMUS: An interesting experiment because my wife mentioned this to me.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: She wants to have sex with you, by the way.

CAVUTO: Who doesn't?

IMUS: I don't. Wants to have sex with you --

CAVUTO: And go ahead.

IMUS: Anyway.

CAVUTO: Come on, Don, tell me. Go ahead, please.

IMUS: Well, I forgot --

CAVUTO: At least say something, you guys.

IMUS: Here is what you should do.

CAVUTO: Like an interview by Rainman.

IMUS: When is the first debate, October 1st?

CAVUTO: I think the 3rd.

IMUS: It's the day he hit the home run. Here is what you should do. Please don't interrupt when I'm talking with Mr. Cavuto, Warner. I'll come over there and beat on you like a rented mule. Just kidding. You should get a group of people.

Frank -- You should do it. Get a group, have them listen to the audio feed and don't let them watch it and have the group just watch it on television and then poll each group to see who won. Who they think won.

CAVUTO: That's not a bad idea.

IMUS: It is a good idea isn't it?

CAVUTO: It's a very good idea.

IMUS: Because Deirdre said to me -- don't you hate it when guys quote their wives. You know, that means they're so p-whipped.

CAVUTO: And she's insane for putting up with you.

IMUS: Absolutely. Because you get distracted who looked and --

CAVUTO: Yes, yes. And history bears that out. I mean, people who, I guess, were listened in to the Nixon-Kennedy debate thought Nixon, and Bush and Al Gore. That was a little more debatable than Kerry and Bush.

IMUS: Should I call Roger and --

CAVUTO: Please do, please do. I'm not going to act on this because I actually think the idea is silly.

IMUS: Do you really?

CAVUTO: Yes. I do.

IMUS: You do?

CAVUTO: I think 90 percent of people are going to be watching and not listening.

IMUS: Well, you're just, I don't know, you're just -- I don't know.

CAVUTO: Well, I just, I think in 1960, it would have been a brilliant idea, but last time I checked --

IMUS: It's a good idea now just to see. It's 18 until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Did you read "Killing Lincoln?"

CAVUTO: I did read it. It's a great book.

IMUS: But I'll tell you what is a terrific book "Killing Kennedy."

CAVUTO: I haven't -- I know it's out or will be out, but-- I really enjoyed "Killing Lincoln", the way he built it up and x number of days to live and I thought when I first opened it, we know what happened in the end.

But he didn't do a great job and see what the Kennedy book, but I think he's got -- he could a series on his hands. I don't know how you handle Philmore, getting Philmore, but --

IMUS: It's enormously entertaining and there's no heavy lifting, not a --

CAVUTO: I think it's a very good point. A lot of the stories, Brinkley, I love dearly and Harry Truman, 900 pages on and on and all great, but you can make this fun and engaging.

IMUS: And accessible.

CAVUTO: It's a way to do it. I didn't see the kids' version that's out but --

IMUS: That's pretty good, too. It's pretty good, too, so, do you think he writes any of it.

CAVUTO: I think he does.

IMUS: What's --

CAVUTO: -- his show.

IMUS: That doesn't make any difference.

CAVUTO: No, it doesn't, but when you say does he write his stuff? Of course, he writes his stuff.

IMUS: How is that demeaning --

CAVUTO: You say does he write the book.

IMUS: As a journalist, I have a --

CAVUTO: Excuse me? Excuse me.

IMUS: It's 17 until the hour here in the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Are you a sports fan?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: Not at all.

CAVUTO: I heard you guys go through the Sunday games. I guess these are football games? Terrific, no offense guns and Warner but --

IMUS: That's fine, but do you ever watch sports on television?

CAVUTO: I have the attention span of a gnat. I watch the highlights. I said, why can't the games be like the highlights?

IMUS: Do you ever watch Sports Center?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: Where do you get the highlights?

CAVUTO: Passing around the news or online, but I'm not really -- I'm afraid I'm not really into it.

IMUS: So, do you watch television?

CAVUTO: I know this is going to sound elitist, but I really don't. I'm just, it's not --

IMUS: Mr. Cavuto --

CAVUTO: I watch you, of course, I mean, that's a staple. Connell and Dagen and flip over --

IMUS: Mr. Cavuto is on at 4 in the afternoon on the Fox News Channel and 8 p.m. and do you think that --

CAVUTO: I want to come back at you with anger, but I saw you with the oxygen tank and go lightly no need to be mean.

IMUS: It's a quarter until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

CAVUTO: This is three times in this hour with this interview, you relay the time. It's always fascinating to me why you do that.

IMUS: I'm doing a radio program.

CAVUTO: I know that. I know, but -- like I say there are clocks in those cars, right?

IMUS: I can stop giving the time.

CAVUTO: OK, more time for me.

IMUS: Bernie, put a call in to Bob -- anyway do you think Obama is a socialist?

CAVUTO: No. I think he likes big government. I think he likes more big government and espouses the view much like FDR in 1932, government the only way to get us out of the mess and a lot more people are beholden to the government as a result of that.

And he's got a pretty good base of people who would vote for him as a result and I think that probably was what Mitt Romney was inelegantly getting at. But we all remember, you know, but FDR got re-elected in a landslide in 36 even though the economy still, still was pretty bad.

IMUS: As ours does.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: And you would think that one of the things that Romney could get some traction and I think, that you asked, I think --

CAVUTO: Your thoughts are very valuable to me.

IMUS: I think the day that Romney gets elected, the economy is better just by -- he doesn't have to do anything, do you agree with that?

CAVUTO: Well, you have to do something. You're popping up in a different --

IMUS: That wasn't the question.

CAVUTO: You mean, well, it's a stupid point. Sounds like Godzilla, January 20th just by virtue of being Godzilla being in the office because it's not Barack Obama, things are better.

IMUS: If it makes you feel like a bigger person, which you're --

CAVUTO: OK, you know, I could lose weight, you will always be evil.

IMUS: To make me feel bad by calling me a list of names, but don't you think the way the markets would react --

CAVUTO: It's always fine until --

IMUS: And the financial community.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: That the things would, people would feel better and I know he has do something, your suit dummy candidate and mine, but wouldn't have to do anything, but just get elected and it would be better. Do you think that's true?

CAVUTO: I don't, I don't, obviously if the nation turns to the challenger to throw the incumbent out of office. It's hoping what you said. And remember, electing Ronald Reagan in a landslide didn't bring results, in fact, the recession many more years and jobs lost until we had to boom in '82.

Coming out of that so things take time, I'm not subscribing to the screw that automatically things are better. They're ready to do well if we don't keep what we're doing and stop with a new guy in there. But you have to do stuff.

You have to put up some initiatives that will change the direction. Ronald Reagan did, and you know, the question would be for Romney administration, if it were to happen, whether it would.

IMUS: Is there a way now to know -- is there a way for you to know who will win the election?

CAVUTO: I have no idea.

IMUS: Do you have a gut sense?

CAVUTO: I do, but I'm not going to share that with you. I will say this - -

IMUS: You're really a creep.

CAVUTO: That's lovely. I only relate this to you. I think I told you this before. When I went to Wisconsin to cover the recall election, polls going into that weekend had dead even. I think it had it dead even and we know at that Walker won by six points.

Now, I had a theory and I could be very wrong that conservative support is understated in some of the state polls, maybe with unwinding a bit it's beyond the margin of error, but I do think these states apparently Mitt Romney is going to get blown out in, I don't subscribe to that.

IMUS: You're going to get to the point eventually, right?

CAVUTO: I just told you. And I think the polls in the battle ground state understate Romney's support.

IMUS: Hope you're right.

CAVUTO: And when you say Romney's my man you always say that.

IMUS: Yes.

CAVUTO: But then you disparage him.

IMUS: Keeping it real.

CAVUTO: And for every wonderful interview like Vince Gill and then you do one like you did with Frank Rich.

IMUS: My job is to keep it real, right, Bernie?

CAVUTO: Frank Rich interview, just kept it real.

IMUS: Keeping it real.

CAVUTO: OK.

IMUS: Thank you very much for --

CAVUTO: This is it?

IMUS: You were on for 12 minutes.

CAVUTO: That's 12 minutes of my life. I'm never getting back.

IMUS: And so does the audience.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACEOD: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. Let's take a look at the markets. In Europe, the "Financial Times" is reporting that European Union authorities are working with the Spanish government to come up with a bailout plan and unlimited bond buying by the European Central Bank.

Markets there are now mixed with London down by about 5 points. Paris is up 10 and Frankfort is up about 64. Here in the U.S., we have seen green arrows across the board all morning. Dow futures are up by 56. The S&P is up by about 5 and the Nasdaq is up by 13.

Now that Apple's iPhone is available, we're also finding out exactly what makes the smartphone work. The repair firm fix it, got one open and chips from Qualcomm, Avago Technologies and Skyworks Solution.

The iPhone also includes an audio chip made by Cirrus Logic and its gyroscope, which is used to track its orientation was made by ST Microelectronics. Keep an eye on those stocks and those are the companies that didn't participate in the iPhone to see the reaction today.

The world's biggest retailer is looking to do business in India. The "Wall Street Journal" reports Wal-Mart hopes to open its first stores in the country within two years. That move comes after the government last week agreed to allow international supermarket chains to enter India through joint ventures.

Wal-Mart says it hadn't decided yet where or how many stores it would like to have, but the company expects to continue its current partnerships with barky enterprises of India, a chain of 17 cash and carry stores.

Here's a look at commodities, oil and gold are up. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on Fox Business.

(IMUS EXTRA SEGMENTS)

END

END

urn:contentItem:5JB0-C061-DY0W-428D-00000-00Apple's iPhone 5 Hitting Store Shelves Around the World; McDonalds, Texas Instruments and Covidien Raise Quarterly Dividends; General Motors2012-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisApple's iPhone 5 Hitting Store Shelves Around the World; McDonalds, Texas Instruments and Covidien Raise Quarterly Dividends; General MotorsLanhamFULL TEXT

DON IMUS, HOST, "IMUS IN THE MORNING": This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the FOX Business Network. Now, here's Diane Macedo.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning, everyone. Apple fans are on the world of lining up to get their hands on the iPhone 5 which hits store shelves around the world today including here in New York City where our own Robert Gray is standing by at Apple's Fifth Avenue store. Robert, it is 6:00 in the morning. What does it look like out there right now?

ROBERT GRAY, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, Diane. Good morning. There are a few hundred folks out here in line behind me. You can see them and in fact, the big cube here which this store is famous for, which lead you to an underground entrance way, the store is normally a 24-7 operation. They closed it overnight. It will not open until 8 a.m. local time. And of course, that is the roll out plan across nine different nations here.

This is the widest rollout that Apple has had yet for one of their iPhones. Now, a key numbers to hit here. We've seen every iPhone new version has outsold a combined total of all the previous versions. This of course is a law of large numbers. It is going to be tough to duplicate. We'll have to wait and see. Most reviewers out there saying this phone a little bit more evolutionary than revolutionary.

And of course, there's been a lot of feedback and flak, if you will, about the new connectors out there. They are of course shrinking the connectors down to nine pins from 30. So, all the products that you have around the house, connectors et cetera, you'll going to have to go out and buy some more of those. So, Apple is expected to make a big hole out of this as well as of course some of their third party partners out there. You're going to talk a little bit all morning long.

Of course, we're expecting a faster processor on board, you got the new ear pods, the camera higher resolution, reportedly better. As the phone even now of course, some reviewers out there and analysts that I've spoken with Diane, saying that as far as the camera goes and processing speed, they're just now catching up to some of the rivals out there. But of course, as you can see, still plenty of Apple fans out here braving the early morning, though we must say pretty mild here in New York City. Back to you.

MACEDO: All right. That's Robert Gray live at the Apple store. Thanks, Robert.

GRAY: You're welcome.

MACEDO: Meanwhile, E.U. anti-trust regulators have cleared universal music group to buy British record company EMI as recorded music unit for $1.9 billion after the Vivendi owned company promised to sell some of EMI's most valuable record labels. Universal says, the assets to be sold amounts to 30 percent of EMI's global sales. Citigroup is selling EMI having acquired the music group when buy-out firm Terra Firma defaulted on loans owed to the investment bank.

Checking the markets now, here in the U.S., futures have been in the green across the board all morning. Dow futures are up by about 40 points. The S&P is up by almost four. The NASDAQ is up by seven.

In Europe, the Financial Times reports European Union authorities are working with the Spanish government to come up with a bailout plan and unlimited bond buying by the European Central Bank. Markets are currently mixed. London was green earlier, now we're seeing it in the red down by almost nine points. Paris and Frankfurt still in the green.

Let's take a closer look at what's moving those markets with Josh Raymond now, chief market strategist at City Index in London. Now, Josh, the FT is reporting that Spain is moving closer to a bailout. Should investors read that as a negative or should they find some release in having some more certainty on that front?

JOSH RAYMOND, CITY INDEX CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST: I think it is a positive. And it does provide some certainty. You know, the markets -- investors have been fairly convinced that more is required. There has been political maneuvering going on with Spain saying that they've got austerity measures in there. They don't require the fully -- bailout. But we already know that they're actually in talks, so we have that -- a few people of the Spanish government actually recently earlier on this week say, it will provide a level of certainty. And I think that would be reacted positively by the market. Of course, it depends on the scale which the (INAUDIBLE) will require, I mean, the ECB through monetary transactions have an unlimited scope to do so as well.

MACEDO: And Josh, Mario Monti is holding meetings in Italy with several leaders today. What do you expect to come out of them?

RAYMOND: Not much unfortunately. And we're getting used to all these meetings taking place and strong rhetoric talking about a fiscal union, stronger banking regulations, that sort of thing but nothing really comes of it. And I think investors are a little bit more wiser to that these days. Now, we already have the ECB. And the main focus for us at the moment really is the ECB and Spain. Now, we've obviously got the -- from the ECB and we're waiting for Spain to confirm or to agree that the terms towards that fully first bailout. Those are the key things that we're looking at.

MACEDO: OK. More brain storming for the many results. We'll see if it comes out that way. Thanks, Josh. That's Josh Raymond from London.

K.B. Home meanwhile is reporting a surprise profit this morning. The home builder says it made four cents a share in its third quarter. The company was expected to lose 16 cents a share but revenue came in light at $424.5 million. The estimate was for 430 million. K.B. Home says, it's order backlog at the end of August rose 18 percent from a year ago to more than 3,100 and home deliveries rose seven percent to more than 1,700.

Here's a quick look at commodities. Oil and gold are both to the upside.

IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on FOX Business.

ANNOUNCER: Ladies and gentlemen, IMUS IN THE MORNING.

IMUS: All right. Well, it's going to be a great show.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes.

IMUS: Great show. Great day in New York today.

MCSHANE: Yep.

IMUS: Last day of summer. Going to be 73 degrees. Let's do some sunbathing, baby.

So, anyway, coming up this morning, Juan Williams, FOX News, and the great Vince Gill. Now, Vince -- when I say great, I mean great. He's not going to sing. He's coming in to talk. Now, why would you book somebody like Vince Gill just to talk? Because he's worth talking to.

MCSHANE: That's it.

IMUS: There's a few of these guys, people who I would talk to. It would be him -- who are worth talking to. Dwight Yoakam.

MCSHANE: OK.

IMUS: Smart guy, Yoakam.

MCSHANE: Uh-huh!

IMUS: Crazy but good crazy. Delbert, smart guy, funny.

MCSHANE: Of course.

IMUS: Kinky.

MCSHANE: Yes, not many more, right?

BERNARD MCGUIRK, PROGRAM PRODUCER: Billy Ray?

LOU RUFINO, PROGRAM PRODUCER: He's one of the nicest guys too, Dwight Yoakam.

MCGUIRK: Oh, yes.

IMUS: He is, isn't he?

RUFINO: Yes, he's really nice guy.

IMUS: You know the day I got fired, he called me on my cell phone. I was on my way to meet the team. And I was in the car.

MCSHANE: Right.

IMUS: He's a good man. He understood what the deal was. And so, you know. You can't say stuff like that, man. Don't pick on people. Just don't do it, whether you're trying to be funny or not. Come on.

Anyway, and so, and then the big dog's here, Bill Clinton.

MCSHANE: Oh, good.

IMUS: He's concerned about this book that Monica Lewinsky is going to do.

MCSHANE: I like that.

IMUS: About them sex positions. And then, Warner?

WARNER WOLF, SPORTSCASTER: Yes.

IMUS: You and Gunz.

MCSHANE: Yes, sir.

IMUS: You skunks. And Steve Mariucci, the pregame show on the NFL Network, there are two reasons to watch that. Other than that.

RUFINO: Yes, good bye.

IMUS: They suck, Rich Eisen, sucks. Steve Mariucci, sucks. Deion Sanders, moron, Michael Irving moron, and that other guy, moron.

MCSHANE: Moron.

IMUS: Every one of them picked the Carolina Panthers. What happened? The New York Giants put a butt whipping on them.

WOLF: Oh, man.

IMUS: Thirty six-seven. Come on.

RUFINO: Pussy riot, come on!

IMUS: Start the pussy riot.

WOLF: That's right. Come on.

IMUS: Oh, man! Eli got the ball, what did he do? He marched down the field and scored a touchdown. Every time he got the ball. Come on!

WOLF: Yes. And the reserves, man, those guys, the regulars better look over their shoulders. Andre Brown playing for Ahmad Bradshaw.

IMUS: Well, you and the ice cream cone on the forehead, Gunzelman --

RUFINO: Oh, wow!

WOLF: Oh, God!

IMUS: -- should have anticipated this.

(TALKING OVER EACH OTHER)

I mean, this was an outrage.

WOLF: That's right.

MACEDO: Good morning, everyone. General Motors is recalling more than 426,000 Chevrolet, Pontiac and Saturn sedans in the U.S. due to transmission problems. The recall affects vehicles model years 2007 to 2010.

The automaker says the transmission gear position may not match the gear on the shifter and that could cause the vehicle to move when drivers think they're in park. GM says it's aware of four crashes due to the problem, but no injuries reported as of now.

Meanwhile, the recall news after General Motors announced it has reached an agreement with the Canadian Autoworkers Union over a labor contract. Under the tentative four year deal, GM will add a third shift to its flex line at its Ontario facility.

The automaker had planned to shutdown that plant three-shift consolidated line next June, but will operate with at least one line until June of 2014. The CAW continues to negotiate a deal with Chrysler after it already reached one with Ford earlier in the week.

IMUS IN THE MORNING continues now after we check the weather with Fox 5 meteorologist, Mike Woods.

MIKE WOODS, FOX 5 METEOROLOGIST: Good morning, everyone. Looks like we have some wet weather out there, but not a ton of it for the country here. We've got an area of low pressure still rotating around the Great Lakes, but it's bringing showers from the Upper Midwest and Central Mississippi Valley area.

And then back towards the rest of the Great Lakes over to the east and also a few showers popping up around Florida again, southeast, slightly risky in terms of showers and storms. Tampa, you'll see a few scattered storms and high temp today, 88 degrees.

And Phoenix, no rain for you, sunny skies with a high of 103 and Seattle partly cloudy skies with a high of 63. Sacramento, California, you've got sunny skies there today with a high of 91, still warm. I'm Mike Woods from Fox 5 in New York.

IMUS: All right, it's 36 minutes past the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Please welcome to the program, senior vice president, anchor manager, Fox Business News, Fox News Channel, a man who sadly calls himself the financial factor, Neil P. Cavuto. What does the P stand for?

NEIL P. CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS: Patrick.

IMUS: Good morning, Mr. Cavuto.

CAVUTO: Good morning, Mr. Imus.

IMUS: How are you?

CAVUTO: It was scary bumping into you this morning.

IMUS: Well, I had my little oxygen tank with me.

CAVUTO: You kind of looked like Hannibal Lector being driven in on a gurney and I thought, is he up to doing the show today? But here you are, encouragement to all us.

IMUS: Well, anaerobic, but I recover quickly and I don't need oxygen just to sit around and talk.

CAVUTO: I admire that.

IMUS: Happy birthday tomorrow.

CAVUTO: How did you know that?

IMUS: It's my job to know those things.

CAVUTO: Thank you very much.

IMUS: So, you like the Vince Gill interview?

CAVUTO: I liked it very much, I'm a big fan of his and I thought you did a very good job. A lot of people, you know, when you interview stars it's always tough. You do a fawning interview or you do a revealing one particularly like the things about your brother, how tough that is and trying to get a handle on it, very real. I liked it very much.

IMUS: So I asked you off the air if you liked Romney. Do you?

CAVUTO: I do, personally I like him a lot.

IMUS: It doesn't bother you that he's a dope, right?

CAVUTO: He's not a dope.

IMUS: OK, he's not a good campaigner, is he?

CAVUTO: I think that remains to be seen. The election hasn't happened yet.

IMUS: No, sir. Do you think that these leaked videos, these missteps that they've each made, is going to make a difference when people vote?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: You don't?

CAVUTO: I do not. I think in the end, it always is the economy. I think that's what-- we could have extenuating circumstances, the Middle East explosion, could have the impact, but almost every U.S. election is decided by the economy.

How good people feel, how maybe not so good people feel and we're always willing to entertain switching horses mid stream when an incumbent is battling a tough economy, but we've really got to see the other horse.

I think in 1980 when the polls were similarly tight between Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. A lot of people liked Jimmy Carter, frustrated with the economy, but they were more than willing to entertain an alternative and along came Ronald Reagan to appeal to alternative.

IMUS: How many people vote for the person who they like the best?

CAVUTO: I think it plays a part.

IMUS: How big a part?

CAVUTO: Well, I do think it helped George Bush, many polls were done on the debate between he and Al Gore and then later on between he and John Kerry. And I think most people said who won the debates?

And a lot of them said, particularly in 2004, with John Kerry, who do you like more or relate to more? George Bush. I'm not saying that's always the case, but it does help if people feel you're either more approachable or likeable.

And I think in 1960 from the television critics later who said that Richard Nixon was sweating and detached and John Kennedy looked relaxed and smooth. These things on some level do connect for people.

IMUS: Talking with Neil Cavuto -- talking with Neil Cavuto here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. It's 5 until the hour, you know what you ought to do here at Fox?

CAVUTO: What's that?

IMUS: An interesting experiment because my wife mentioned this to me.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: She wants to have sex with you, by the way.

CAVUTO: Who doesn't?

IMUS: I don't. Wants to have sex with you --

CAVUTO: And go ahead.

IMUS: Anyway.

CAVUTO: Come on, Don, tell me. Go ahead, please.

IMUS: Well, I forgot --

CAVUTO: At least say something, you guys.

IMUS: Here is what you should do.

CAVUTO: Like an interview by Rainman.

IMUS: When is the first debate, October 1st?

CAVUTO: I think the 3rd.

IMUS: It's the day he hit the home run. Here is what you should do. Please don't interrupt when I'm talking with Mr. Cavuto, Warner. I'll come over there and beat on you like a rented mule. Just kidding. You should get a group of people.

Frank -- You should do it. Get a group, have them listen to the audio feed and don't let them watch it and have the group just watch it on television and then poll each group to see who won. Who they think won.

CAVUTO: That's not a bad idea.

IMUS: It is a good idea isn't it?

CAVUTO: It's a very good idea.

IMUS: Because Deirdre said to me -- don't you hate it when guys quote their wives. You know, that means they're so p-whipped.

CAVUTO: And she's insane for putting up with you.

IMUS: Absolutely. Because you get distracted who looked and --

CAVUTO: Yes, yes. And history bears that out. I mean, people who, I guess, were listened in to the Nixon-Kennedy debate thought Nixon, and Bush and Al Gore. That was a little more debatable than Kerry and Bush.

IMUS: Should I call Roger and --

CAVUTO: Please do, please do. I'm not going to act on this because I actually think the idea is silly.

IMUS: Do you really?

CAVUTO: Yes. I do.

IMUS: You do?

CAVUTO: I think 90 percent of people are going to be watching and not listening.

IMUS: Well, you're just, I don't know, you're just -- I don't know.

CAVUTO: Well, I just, I think in 1960, it would have been a brilliant idea, but last time I checked --

IMUS: It's a good idea now just to see. It's 18 until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Did you read "Killing Lincoln?"

CAVUTO: I did read it. It's a great book.

IMUS: But I'll tell you what is a terrific book "Killing Kennedy."

CAVUTO: I haven't -- I know it's out or will be out, but-- I really enjoyed "Killing Lincoln", the way he built it up and x number of days to live and I thought when I first opened it, we know what happened in the end.

But he didn't do a great job and see what the Kennedy book, but I think he's got -- he could a series on his hands. I don't know how you handle Philmore, getting Philmore, but --

IMUS: It's enormously entertaining and there's no heavy lifting, not a --

CAVUTO: I think it's a very good point. A lot of the stories, Brinkley, I love dearly and Harry Truman, 900 pages on and on and all great, but you can make this fun and engaging.

IMUS: And accessible.

CAVUTO: It's a way to do it. I didn't see the kids' version that's out but --

IMUS: That's pretty good, too. It's pretty good, too, so, do you think he writes any of it.

CAVUTO: I think he does.

IMUS: What's --

CAVUTO: -- his show.

IMUS: That doesn't make any difference.

CAVUTO: No, it doesn't, but when you say does he write his stuff? Of course, he writes his stuff.

IMUS: How is that demeaning --

CAVUTO: You say does he write the book.

IMUS: As a journalist, I have a --

CAVUTO: Excuse me? Excuse me.

IMUS: It's 17 until the hour here in the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Are you a sports fan?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: Not at all.

CAVUTO: I heard you guys go through the Sunday games. I guess these are football games? Terrific, no offense guns and Warner but --

IMUS: That's fine, but do you ever watch sports on television?

CAVUTO: I have the attention span of a gnat. I watch the highlights. I said, why can't the games be like the highlights?

IMUS: Do you ever watch Sports Center?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: Where do you get the highlights?

CAVUTO: Passing around the news or online, but I'm not really -- I'm afraid I'm not really into it.

IMUS: So, do you watch television?

CAVUTO: I know this is going to sound elitist, but I really don't. I'm just, it's not --

IMUS: Mr. Cavuto --

CAVUTO: I watch you, of course, I mean, that's a staple. Connell and Dagen and flip over --

IMUS: Mr. Cavuto is on at 4 in the afternoon on the Fox News Channel and 8 p.m. and do you think that --

CAVUTO: I want to come back at you with anger, but I saw you with the oxygen tank and go lightly no need to be mean.

IMUS: It's a quarter until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

CAVUTO: This is three times in this hour with this interview, you relay the time. It's always fascinating to me why you do that.

IMUS: I'm doing a radio program.

CAVUTO: I know that. I know, but -- like I say there are clocks in those cars, right?

IMUS: I can stop giving the time.

CAVUTO: OK, more time for me.

IMUS: Bernie, put a call in to Bob -- anyway do you think Obama is a socialist?

CAVUTO: No. I think he likes big government. I think he likes more big government and espouses the view much like FDR in 1932, government the only way to get us out of the mess and a lot more people are beholden to the government as a result of that.

And he's got a pretty good base of people who would vote for him as a result and I think that probably was what Mitt Romney was inelegantly getting at. But we all remember, you know, but FDR got re-elected in a landslide in 36 even though the economy still, still was pretty bad.

IMUS: As ours does.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: And you would think that one of the things that Romney could get some traction and I think, that you asked, I think --

CAVUTO: Your thoughts are very valuable to me.

IMUS: I think the day that Romney gets elected, the economy is better just by -- he doesn't have to do anything, do you agree with that?

CAVUTO: Well, you have to do something. You're popping up in a different --

IMUS: That wasn't the question.

CAVUTO: You mean, well, it's a stupid point. Sounds like Godzilla, January 20th just by virtue of being Godzilla being in the office because it's not Barack Obama, things are better.

IMUS: If it makes you feel like a bigger person, which you're --

CAVUTO: OK, you know, I could lose weight, you will always be evil.

IMUS: To make me feel bad by calling me a list of names, but don't you think the way the markets would react --

CAVUTO: It's always fine until --

IMUS: And the financial community.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: That the things would, people would feel better and I know he has do something, your suit dummy candidate and mine, but wouldn't have to do anything, but just get elected and it would be better. Do you think that's true?

CAVUTO: I don't, I don't, obviously if the nation turns to the challenger to throw the incumbent out of office. It's hoping what you said. And remember, electing Ronald Reagan in a landslide didn't bring results, in fact, the recession many more years and jobs lost until we had to boom in '82.

Coming out of that so things take time, I'm not subscribing to the screw that automatically things are better. They're ready to do well if we don't keep what we're doing and stop with a new guy in there. But you have to do stuff.

You have to put up some initiatives that will change the direction. Ronald Reagan did, and you know, the question would be for Romney administration, if it were to happen, whether it would.

IMUS: Is there a way now to know -- is there a way for you to know who will win the election?

CAVUTO: I have no idea.

IMUS: Do you have a gut sense?

CAVUTO: I do, but I'm not going to share that with you. I will say this - -

IMUS: You're really a creep.

CAVUTO: That's lovely. I only relate this to you. I think I told you this before. When I went to Wisconsin to cover the recall election, polls going into that weekend had dead even. I think it had it dead even and we know at that Walker won by six points.

Now, I had a theory and I could be very wrong that conservative support is understated in some of the state polls, maybe with unwinding a bit it's beyond the margin of error, but I do think these states apparently Mitt Romney is going to get blown out in, I don't subscribe to that.

IMUS: You're going to get to the point eventually, right?

CAVUTO: I just told you. And I think the polls in the battle ground state understate Romney's support.

IMUS: Hope you're right.

CAVUTO: And when you say Romney's my man you always say that.

IMUS: Yes.

CAVUTO: But then you disparage him.

IMUS: Keeping it real.

CAVUTO: And for every wonderful interview like Vince Gill and then you do one like you did with Frank Rich.

IMUS: My job is to keep it real, right, Bernie?

CAVUTO: Frank Rich interview, just kept it real.

IMUS: Keeping it real.

CAVUTO: OK.

IMUS: Thank you very much for --

CAVUTO: This is it?

IMUS: You were on for 12 minutes.

CAVUTO: That's 12 minutes of my life. I'm never getting back.

IMUS: And so does the audience.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACEOD: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. Let's take a look at the markets. In Europe, the "Financial Times" is reporting that European Union authorities are working with the Spanish government to come up with a bailout plan and unlimited bond buying by the European Central Bank.

Markets there are now mixed with London down by about 5 points. Paris is up 10 and Frankfort is up about 64. Here in the U.S., we have seen green arrows across the board all morning. Dow futures are up by 56. The S&P is up by about 5 and the Nasdaq is up by 13.

Now that Apple's iPhone is available, we're also finding out exactly what makes the smartphone work. The repair firm fix it, got one open and chips from Qualcomm, Avago Technologies and Skyworks Solution.

The iPhone also includes an audio chip made by Cirrus Logic and its gyroscope, which is used to track its orientation was made by ST Microelectronics. Keep an eye on those stocks and those are the companies that didn't participate in the iPhone to see the reaction today.

The world's biggest retailer is looking to do business in India. The "Wall Street Journal" reports Wal-Mart hopes to open its first stores in the country within two years. That move comes after the government last week agreed to allow international supermarket chains to enter India through joint ventures.

Wal-Mart says it hadn't decided yet where or how many stores it would like to have, but the company expects to continue its current partnerships with barky enterprises of India, a chain of 17 cash and carry stores.

Here's a look at commodities, oil and gold are up. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on Fox Business.

(IMUS EXTRA SEGMENTS)

END

urn:contentItem:56NB-V8D1-F0HW-50XK-00000-00Apple's iPhone 5 Hitting Store Shelves Around the World; McDonalds, Texas Instruments and Covidien Raise Quarterly Dividends; General Motors2012-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisApple's iPhone 5 Hitting Store Shelves Around the World; McDonalds, Texas Instruments and Covidien Raise Quarterly Dividends; General Motors

DON IMUS, HOST, "IMUS IN THE MORNING": This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the FOX Business Network. Now, here's Diane Macedo.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning, everyone. Apple fans are on the world of lining up to get their hands on the iPhone 5 which hits store shelves around the world today including here in New York City where our own Robert Gray is standing by at Apple's Fifth Avenue store. Robert, it is 6:00 in the morning. What does it look like out there right now?

ROBERT GRAY, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, Diane. Good morning. There are a few hundred folks out here in line behind me. You can see them and in fact, the big cube here which this store is famous for, which lead you to an underground entrance way, the store is normally a 24-7 operation. They closed it overnight. It will not open until 8 a.m. local time. And of course, that is the roll out plan across nine different nations here.

This is the widest rollout that Apple has had yet for one of their iPhones. Now, a key numbers to hit here. We've seen every iPhone new version has outsold a combined total of all the previous versions. This of course is a law of large numbers. It is going to be tough to duplicate. We'll have to wait and see. Most reviewers out there saying this phone a little bit more evolutionary than revolutionary.

And of course, there's been a lot of feedback and flak, if you will, about the new connectors out there. They are of course shrinking the connectors down to nine pins from 30. So, all the products that you have around the house, connectors et cetera, you'll going to have to go out and buy some more of those. So, Apple is expected to make a big hole out of this as well as of course some of their third party partners out there. You're going to talk a little bit all morning long.

Of course, we're expecting a faster processor on board, you got the new ear pods, the camera higher resolution, reportedly better. As the phone even now of course, some reviewers out there and analysts that I've spoken with Diane, saying that as far as the camera goes and processing speed, they're just now catching up to some of the rivals out there. But of course, as you can see, still plenty of Apple fans out here braving the early morning, though we must say pretty mild here in New York City. Back to you.

MACEDO: All right. That's Robert Gray live at the Apple store. Thanks, Robert.

GRAY: You're welcome.

MACEDO: Meanwhile, E.U. anti-trust regulators have cleared universal music group to buy British record company EMI as recorded music unit for $1.9 billion after the Vivendi owned company promised to sell some of EMI's most valuable record labels. Universal says, the assets to be sold amounts to 30 percent of EMI's global sales. Citigroup is selling EMI having acquired the music group when buy-out firm Terra Firma defaulted on loans owed to the investment bank.

Checking the markets now, here in the U.S., futures have been in the green across the board all morning. Dow futures are up by about 40 points. The S&P is up by almost four. The NASDAQ is up by seven.

In Europe, the Financial Times reports European Union authorities are working with the Spanish government to come up with a bailout plan and unlimited bond buying by the European Central Bank. Markets are currently mixed. London was green earlier, now we're seeing it in the red down by almost nine points. Paris and Frankfurt still in the green.

Let's take a closer look at what's moving those markets with Josh Raymond now, chief market strategist at City Index in London. Now, Josh, the FT is reporting that Spain is moving closer to a bailout. Should investors read that as a negative or should they find some release in having some more certainty on that front?

JOSH RAYMOND, CITY INDEX CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST: I think it is a positive. And it does provide some certainty. You know, the markets -- investors have been fairly convinced that more is required. There has been political maneuvering going on with Spain saying that they've got austerity measures in there. They don't require the fully -- bailout. But we already know that they're actually in talks, so we have that -- a few people of the Spanish government actually recently earlier on this week say, it will provide a level of certainty. And I think that would be reacted positively by the market. Of course, it depends on the scale which the (INAUDIBLE) will require, I mean, the ECB through monetary transactions have an unlimited scope to do so as well.

MACEDO: And Josh, Mario Monti is holding meetings in Italy with several leaders today. What do you expect to come out of them?

RAYMOND: Not much unfortunately. And we're getting used to all these meetings taking place and strong rhetoric talking about a fiscal union, stronger banking regulations, that sort of thing but nothing really comes of it. And I think investors are a little bit more wiser to that these days. Now, we already have the ECB. And the main focus for us at the moment really is the ECB and Spain. Now, we've obviously got the -- from the ECB and we're waiting for Spain to confirm or to agree that the terms towards that fully first bailout. Those are the key things that we're looking at.

MACEDO: OK. More brain storming for the many results. We'll see if it comes out that way. Thanks, Josh. That's Josh Raymond from London.

K.B. Home meanwhile is reporting a surprise profit this morning. The home builder says it made four cents a share in its third quarter. The company was expected to lose 16 cents a share but revenue came in light at $424.5 million. The estimate was for 430 million. K.B. Home says, it's order backlog at the end of August rose 18 percent from a year ago to more than 3,100 and home deliveries rose seven percent to more than 1,700.

Here's a quick look at commodities. Oil and gold are both to the upside.

MCGUIRK: The way he just -- I mean, did he ask him about the memoir that's coming out? --

IMUS: Oh, no --

MCGUIRK: Memoir --

IMUS: Stewart was jerking his chain.

MCGUIRK: No, he wasn't.

IMUS: Yes, he was.

MCGUIRK: I saw it. He was --

IMUS: He wasn't jerking his chain?

MCGUIRK: Not at all. He was telling him what a great speech you gave and could you put facts out there, unlike Mitt Romney --

IMUS: You're telling me Stewart wasn't kidding with that?

MCGUIRK: No, not at all. That was a straight-up journalistic --

IMUS: Didn't he sound like he was kidding --

BARTLETT: I mean, I didn't see it, so, I mean, I was there?

IMUS: He didn't sound like he was kidding?

POWELL: Little tongue in cheek to me.

IMUS: That's what he sounded, like a little tongue in cheek. Really?

MCGUIRK: No, absolutely not.

IMUS: Well, because you're a hater.

MCGUIRK: No, because I actually watched it, I saw it. Now, let's move on here, boss, because the clock is ticking and I know you want to get Mr. Cavuto on.

MCSHANE: Yes.

MCGUIRK: And we got us a little sex scandal over at "Good Morning America".

IMUS: All right.

MCGUIRK: You know, locally here in New York City, you have this news anchor on "Channel 7", "Wabc" Liz Cho.

IMUS: Oh, my God, that's a home wrecker there.

MCGUIRK: Well, excuse me. She and this dude, Josh Elliott, who's an anchor on "Good Morning America", they're apparently an item. I'm going to read from the "New York Post" --

IMUS: I thought she was married.

MCGUIRK: Well, she was.

IMUS: Oh --

MCGUIRK: This is what the "New York Post" page six writes this morning. "After we revealed yesterday that 41-year-old beauty Cho, the co-anchor of "Wabc TV" in New York, split with her husband and moved out of their Yonkers mansion three months ago.

She insisted through friends that they're just friends. She's 41, he's 41 and they say "That this guy Elliott is a regular visitor to Liz's new apartment on west 90th street, baby.

And he's been spotted leaving the building in the morning. He's even been picked up from Cho's part to head to work at "Good Morning America" where he works as a news anchor.

Good morning Elizabeth. But they insists that the relationship began after she moved out of the Yonkers mansion.

IMUS: OK.

MCGUIRK: Right, it has to be true, right?

RUFINO: All right.

MCGUIRK: Yes, but in any case, you know this guy Josh Elliott, he's sort of in Kris Humphries area, he hosts this unwatchable "Good Afternoon America" show --

IMUS: No, I don't --

MCGUIRK: With Lara Spencer. Well, anyway this is blooming over --

IMUS: Stuff about praising anchor, no, I don't.

MCGUIRK: And they're beating the crap out of the "Today Show" by the way - -

IMUS: Not good, I'm happy about that.

MCSHANE: Yes.

MCGUIRK: Yes.

IMUS: That's all you got?

MCGUIRK: Well, I do have another piece of David Letterman clip, busting on Jay Leno and Mitt Romney, but --

IMUS: No, he's a creep --

MCGUIRK: We can save it.

IMUS: Thirty minutes after the hour, and here, Cavuto is next.

One of Neil's favorite songs.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the Fox Business Network. And now, here is Diane Macedo.

MACEDO: Good morning, everyone. General Motors is recalling more than 426,000 Chevrolet, Pontiac and Saturn sedans in the U.S. due to transmission problems. The recall affects vehicles model years 2007 to 2010.

The automaker says the transmission gear position may not match the gear on the shifter and that could cause the vehicle to move when drivers think they're in park. GM says it's aware of four crashes due to the problem, but no injuries reported as of now.

Meanwhile, the recall news after General Motors announced it has reached an agreement with the Canadian Autoworkers Union over a labor contract. Under the tentative four year deal, GM will add a third shift to its flex line at its Ontario facility.

The automaker had planned to shutdown that plant three-shift consolidated line next June, but will operate with at least one line until June of 2014. The CAW continues to negotiate a deal with Chrysler after it already reached one with Ford earlier in the week.

IMUS IN THE MORNING continues now after we check the weather with Fox 5 meteorologist, Mike Woods.

MIKE WOODS, FOX 5 METEOROLOGIST: Good morning, everyone. Looks like we have some wet weather out there, but not a ton of it for the country here. We've got an area of low pressure still rotating around the Great Lakes, but it's bringing showers from the Upper Midwest and Central Mississippi Valley area.

And then back towards the rest of the Great Lakes over to the east and also a few showers popping up around Florida again, southeast, slightly risky in terms of showers and storms. Tampa, you'll see a few scattered storms and high temp today, 88 degrees.

And Phoenix, no rain for you, sunny skies with a high of 103 and Seattle partly cloudy skies with a high of 63. Sacramento, California, you've got sunny skies there today with a high of 91, still warm. I'm Mike Woods from Fox 5 in New York.

IMUS: All right, it's 36 minutes past the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Please welcome to the program, senior vice president, anchor manager, Fox Business News, Fox News Channel, a man who sadly calls himself the financial factor, Neil P. Cavuto. What does the P stand for?

NEIL P. CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS: Patrick.

IMUS: Good morning, Mr. Cavuto.

CAVUTO: Good morning, Mr. Imus.

IMUS: How are you?

CAVUTO: It was scary bumping into you this morning.

IMUS: Well, I had my little oxygen tank with me.

CAVUTO: You kind of looked like Hannibal Lector being driven in on a gurney and I thought, is he up to doing the show today? But here you are, encouragement to all us.

IMUS: Well, anaerobic, but I recover quickly and I don't need oxygen just to sit around and talk.

CAVUTO: I admire that.

IMUS: Happy birthday tomorrow.

CAVUTO: How did you know that?

IMUS: It's my job to know those things.

CAVUTO: Thank you very much.

IMUS: So, you like the Vince Gill interview?

CAVUTO: I liked it very much, I'm a big fan of his and I thought you did a very good job. A lot of people, you know, when you interview stars it's always tough. You do a fawning interview or you do a revealing one particularly like the things about your brother, how tough that is and trying to get a handle on it, very real. I liked it very much.

IMUS: So I asked you off the air if you liked Romney. Do you?

CAVUTO: I do, personally I like him a lot.

IMUS: It doesn't bother you that he's a dope, right?

CAVUTO: He's not a dope.

IMUS: OK, he's not a good campaigner, is he?

CAVUTO: I think that remains to be seen. The election hasn't happened yet.

IMUS: No, sir. Do you think that these leaked videos, these missteps that they've each made, is going to make a difference when people vote?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: You don't?

CAVUTO: I do not. I think in the end, it always is the economy. I think that's what-- we could have extenuating circumstances, the Middle East explosion, could have the impact, but almost every U.S. election is decided by the economy.

How good people feel, how maybe not so good people feel and we're always willing to entertain switching horses mid stream when an incumbent is battling a tough economy, but we've really got to see the other horse.

I think in 1980 when the polls were similarly tight between Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. A lot of people liked Jimmy Carter, frustrated with the economy, but they were more than willing to entertain an alternative and along came Ronald Reagan to appeal to alternative.

IMUS: How many people vote for the person who they like the best?

CAVUTO: I think it plays a part.

IMUS: How big a part?

CAVUTO: Well, I do think it helped George Bush, many polls were done on the debate between he and Al Gore and then later on between he and John Kerry. And I think most people said who won the debates?

And a lot of them said, particularly in 2004, with John Kerry, who do you like more or relate to more? George Bush. I'm not saying that's always the case, but it does help if people feel you're either more approachable or likeable.

And I think in 1960 from the television critics later who said that Richard Nixon was sweating and detached and John Kennedy looked relaxed and smooth. These things on some level do connect for people.

IMUS: Talking with Neil Cavuto -- talking with Neil Cavuto here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. It's 5 until the hour, you know what you ought to do here at Fox?

CAVUTO: What's that?

IMUS: An interesting experiment because my wife mentioned this to me.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: She wants to have sex with you, by the way.

CAVUTO: Who doesn't?

IMUS: I don't. Wants to have sex with you --

CAVUTO: And go ahead.

IMUS: Anyway.

CAVUTO: Come on, Don, tell me. Go ahead, please.

IMUS: Well, I forgot --

CAVUTO: At least say something, you guys.

IMUS: Here is what you should do.

CAVUTO: Like an interview by Rainman.

IMUS: When is the first debate, October 1st?

CAVUTO: I think the 3rd.

IMUS: It's the day he hit the home run. Here is what you should do. Please don't interrupt when I'm talking with Mr. Cavuto, Warner. I'll come over there and beat on you like a rented mule. Just kidding. You should get a group of people.

Frank -- You should do it. Get a group, have them listen to the audio feed and don't let them watch it and have the group just watch it on television and then poll each group to see who won. Who they think won.

CAVUTO: That's not a bad idea.

IMUS: It is a good idea isn't it?

CAVUTO: It's a very good idea.

IMUS: Because Deirdre said to me -- don't you hate it when guys quote their wives. You know, that means they're so p-whipped.

CAVUTO: And she's insane for putting up with you.

IMUS: Absolutely. Because you get distracted who looked and --

CAVUTO: Yes, yes. And history bears that out. I mean, people who, I guess, were listened in to the Nixon-Kennedy debate thought Nixon, and Bush and Al Gore. That was a little more debatable than Kerry and Bush.

IMUS: Should I call Roger and --

CAVUTO: Please do, please do. I'm not going to act on this because I actually think the idea is silly.

IMUS: Do you really?

CAVUTO: Yes. I do.

IMUS: You do?

CAVUTO: I think 90 percent of people are going to be watching and not listening.

IMUS: Well, you're just, I don't know, you're just -- I don't know.

CAVUTO: Well, I just, I think in 1960, it would have been a brilliant idea, but last time I checked --

IMUS: It's a good idea now just to see. It's 18 until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Did you read "Killing Lincoln?"

CAVUTO: I did read it. It's a great book.

IMUS: But I'll tell you what is a terrific book "Killing Kennedy."

CAVUTO: I haven't -- I know it's out or will be out, but-- I really enjoyed "Killing Lincoln", the way he built it up and x number of days to live and I thought when I first opened it, we know what happened in the end.

But he didn't do a great job and see what the Kennedy book, but I think he's got -- he could a series on his hands. I don't know how you handle Philmore, getting Philmore, but --

IMUS: It's enormously entertaining and there's no heavy lifting, not a --

CAVUTO: I think it's a very good point. A lot of the stories, Brinkley, I love dearly and Harry Truman, 900 pages on and on and all great, but you can make this fun and engaging.

IMUS: And accessible.

CAVUTO: It's a way to do it. I didn't see the kids' version that's out but --

IMUS: That's pretty good, too. It's pretty good, too, so, do you think he writes any of it.

CAVUTO: I think he does.

IMUS: What's --

CAVUTO: -- his show.

IMUS: That doesn't make any difference.

CAVUTO: No, it doesn't, but when you say does he write his stuff? Of course, he writes his stuff.

IMUS: How is that demeaning --

CAVUTO: You say does he write the book.

IMUS: As a journalist, I have a --

CAVUTO: Excuse me? Excuse me.

IMUS: It's 17 until the hour here in the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Are you a sports fan?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: Not at all.

CAVUTO: I heard you guys go through the Sunday games. I guess these are football games? Terrific, no offense guns and Warner but --

IMUS: That's fine, but do you ever watch sports on television?

CAVUTO: I have the attention span of a gnat. I watch the highlights. I said, why can't the games be like the highlights?

IMUS: Do you ever watch Sports Center?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: Where do you get the highlights?

CAVUTO: Passing around the news or online, but I'm not really -- I'm afraid I'm not really into it.

IMUS: So, do you watch television?

CAVUTO: I know this is going to sound elitist, but I really don't. I'm just, it's not --

IMUS: Mr. Cavuto --

CAVUTO: I watch you, of course, I mean, that's a staple. Connell and Dagen and flip over --

IMUS: Mr. Cavuto is on at 4 in the afternoon on the Fox News Channel and 8 p.m. and do you think that --

CAVUTO: I want to come back at you with anger, but I saw you with the oxygen tank and go lightly no need to be mean.

IMUS: It's a quarter until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

CAVUTO: This is three times in this hour with this interview, you relay the time. It's always fascinating to me why you do that.

IMUS: I'm doing a radio program.

CAVUTO: I know that. I know, but -- like I say there are clocks in those cars, right?

IMUS: I can stop giving the time.

CAVUTO: OK, more time for me.

IMUS: Bernie, put a call in to Bob -- anyway do you think Obama is a socialist?

CAVUTO: No. I think he likes big government. I think he likes more big government and espouses the view much like FDR in 1932, government the only way to get us out of the mess and a lot more people are beholden to the government as a result of that.

And he's got a pretty good base of people who would vote for him as a result and I think that probably was what Mitt Romney was inelegantly getting at. But we all remember, you know, but FDR got re-elected in a landslide in 36 even though the economy still, still was pretty bad.

IMUS: As ours does.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: And you would think that one of the things that Romney could get some traction and I think, that you asked, I think --

CAVUTO: Your thoughts are very valuable to me.

IMUS: I think the day that Romney gets elected, the economy is better just by -- he doesn't have to do anything, do you agree with that?

CAVUTO: Well, you have to do something. You're popping up in a different --

IMUS: That wasn't the question.

CAVUTO: You mean, well, it's a stupid point. Sounds like Godzilla, January 20th just by virtue of being Godzilla being in the office because it's not Barack Obama, things are better.

IMUS: If it makes you feel like a bigger person, which you're --

CAVUTO: OK, you know, I could lose weight, you will always be evil.

IMUS: To make me feel bad by calling me a list of names, but don't you think the way the markets would react --

CAVUTO: It's always fine until --

IMUS: And the financial community.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: That the things would, people would feel better and I know he has do something, your suit dummy candidate and mine, but wouldn't have to do anything, but just get elected and it would be better. Do you think that's true?

CAVUTO: I don't, I don't, obviously if the nation turns to the challenger to throw the incumbent out of office. It's hoping what you said. And remember, electing Ronald Reagan in a landslide didn't bring results, in fact, the recession many more years and jobs lost until we had to boom in '82.

Coming out of that so things take time, I'm not subscribing to the screw that automatically things are better. They're ready to do well if we don't keep what we're doing and stop with a new guy in there. But you have to do stuff.

You have to put up some initiatives that will change the direction. Ronald Reagan did, and you know, the question would be for Romney administration, if it were to happen, whether it would.

IMUS: Is there a way now to know -- is there a way for you to know who will win the election?

CAVUTO: I have no idea.

IMUS: Do you have a gut sense?

CAVUTO: I do, but I'm not going to share that with you. I will say this - -

IMUS: You're really a creep.

CAVUTO: That's lovely. I only relate this to you. I think I told you this before. When I went to Wisconsin to cover the recall election, polls going into that weekend had dead even. I think it had it dead even and we know at that Walker won by six points.

Now, I had a theory and I could be very wrong that conservative support is understated in some of the state polls, maybe with unwinding a bit it's beyond the margin of error, but I do think these states apparently Mitt Romney is going to get blown out in, I don't subscribe to that.

IMUS: You're going to get to the point eventually, right?

CAVUTO: I just told you. And I think the polls in the battle ground state understate Romney's support.

IMUS: Hope you're right.

CAVUTO: And when you say Romney's my man you always say that.

IMUS: Yes.

CAVUTO: But then you disparage him.

IMUS: Keeping it real.

CAVUTO: And for every wonderful interview like Vince Gill and then you do one like you did with Frank Rich.

IMUS: My job is to keep it real, right, Bernie?

CAVUTO: Frank Rich interview, just kept it real.

IMUS: Keeping it real.

CAVUTO: OK.

IMUS: Thank you very much for --

CAVUTO: This is it?

IMUS: You were on for 12 minutes.

CAVUTO: That's 12 minutes of my life. I'm never getting back.

IMUS: And so does the audience.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACEOD: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. Let's take a look at the markets. In Europe, the "Financial Times" is reporting that European Union authorities are working with the Spanish government to come up with a bailout plan and unlimited bond buying by the European Central Bank.

Markets there are now mixed with London down by about 5 points. Paris is up 10 and Frankfort is up about 64. Here in the U.S., we have seen green arrows across the board all morning. Dow futures are up by 56. The S&P is up by about 5 and the Nasdaq is up by 13.

Now that Apple's iPhone is available, we're also finding out exactly what makes the smartphone work. The repair firm fix it, got one open and chips from Qualcomm, Avago Technologies and Skyworks Solution.

The iPhone also includes an audio chip made by Cirrus Logic and its gyroscope, which is used to track its orientation was made by ST Microelectronics. Keep an eye on those stocks and those are the companies that didn't participate in the iPhone to see the reaction today.

The world's biggest retailer is looking to do business in India. The "Wall Street Journal" reports Wal-Mart hopes to open its first stores in the country within two years. That move comes after the government last week agreed to allow international supermarket chains to enter India through joint ventures.

Wal-Mart says it hadn't decided yet where or how many stores it would like to have, but the company expects to continue its current partnerships with barky enterprises of India, a chain of 17 cash and carry stores.

Here's a look at commodities, oil and gold are up. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on Fox Business.

(IMUS EXTRA SEGMENTS)

END

END

urn:contentItem:56NC-7WB1-JDTY-42PT-00000-00Apple's iPhone 5 Hitting Store Shelves Around the World; McDonalds, Texas Instruments and Covidien Raise Quarterly Dividends; General Motors2012-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisApple's iPhone 5 Hitting Store Shelves Around the World; McDonalds, Texas Instruments and Covidien Raise Quarterly Dividends; General Motors

DON IMUS, HOST, "IMUS IN THE MORNING": This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the FOX Business Network. Now, here's Diane Macedo.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning, everyone. Apple fans are on the world of lining up to get their hands on the iPhone 5 which hits store shelves around the world today including here in New York City where our own Robert Gray is standing by at Apple's Fifth Avenue store. Robert, it is 6:00 in the morning. What does it look like out there right now?

ROBERT GRAY, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, Diane. Good morning. There are a few hundred folks out here in line behind me. You can see them and in fact, the big cube here which this store is famous for, which lead you to an underground entrance way, the store is normally a 24-7 operation. They closed it overnight. It will not open until 8 a.m. local time. And of course, that is the roll out plan across nine different nations here.

This is the widest rollout that Apple has had yet for one of their iPhones. Now, a key numbers to hit here. We've seen every iPhone new version has outsold a combined total of all the previous versions. This of course is a law of large numbers. It is going to be tough to duplicate. We'll have to wait and see. Most reviewers out there saying this phone a little bit more evolutionary than revolutionary.

And of course, there's been a lot of feedback and flak, if you will, about the new connectors out there. They are of course shrinking the connectors down to nine pins from 30. So, all the products that you have around the house, connectors et cetera, you'll going to have to go out and buy some more of those. So, Apple is expected to make a big hole out of this as well as of course some of their third party partners out there. You're going to talk a little bit all morning long.

Of course, we're expecting a faster processor on board, you got the new ear pods, the camera higher resolution, reportedly better. As the phone even now of course, some reviewers out there and analysts that I've spoken with Diane, saying that as far as the camera goes and processing speed, they're just now catching up to some of the rivals out there. But of course, as you can see, still plenty of Apple fans out here braving the early morning, though we must say pretty mild here in New York City. Back to you.

MACEDO: All right. That's Robert Gray live at the Apple store. Thanks, Robert.

GRAY: You're welcome.

MACEDO: Meanwhile, E.U. anti-trust regulators have cleared universal music group to buy British record company EMI as recorded music unit for $1.9 billion after the Vivendi owned company promised to sell some of EMI's most valuable record labels. Universal says, the assets to be sold amounts to 30 percent of EMI's global sales. Citigroup is selling EMI having acquired the music group when buy-out firm Terra Firma defaulted on loans owed to the investment bank.

Checking the markets now, here in the U.S., futures have been in the green across the board all morning. Dow futures are up by about 40 points. The S&P is up by almost four. The NASDAQ is up by seven.

In Europe, the Financial Times reports European Union authorities are working with the Spanish government to come up with a bailout plan and unlimited bond buying by the European Central Bank. Markets are currently mixed. London was green earlier, now we're seeing it in the red down by almost nine points. Paris and Frankfurt still in the green.

Let's take a closer look at what's moving those markets with Josh Raymond now, chief market strategist at City Index in London. Now, Josh, the FT is reporting that Spain is moving closer to a bailout. Should investors read that as a negative or should they find some release in having some more certainty on that front?

JOSH RAYMOND, CITY INDEX CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST: I think it is a positive. And it does provide some certainty. You know, the markets -- investors have been fairly convinced that more is required. There has been political maneuvering going on with Spain saying that they've got austerity measures in there. They don't require the fully -- bailout. But we already know that they're actually in talks, so we have that -- a few people of the Spanish government actually recently earlier on this week say, it will provide a level of certainty. And I think that would be reacted positively by the market. Of course, it depends on the scale which the (INAUDIBLE) will require, I mean, the ECB through monetary transactions have an unlimited scope to do so as well.

MACEDO: And Josh, Mario Monti is holding meetings in Italy with several leaders today. What do you expect to come out of them?

RAYMOND: Not much unfortunately. And we're getting used to all these meetings taking place and strong rhetoric talking about a fiscal union, stronger banking regulations, that sort of thing but nothing really comes of it. And I think investors are a little bit more wiser to that these days. Now, we already have the ECB. And the main focus for us at the moment really is the ECB and Spain. Now, we've obviously got the -- from the ECB and we're waiting for Spain to confirm or to agree that the terms towards that fully first bailout. Those are the key things that we're looking at.

MACEDO: OK. More brain storming for the many results. We'll see if it comes out that way. Thanks, Josh. That's Josh Raymond from London.

K.B. Home meanwhile is reporting a surprise profit this morning. The home builder says it made four cents a share in its third quarter. The company was expected to lose 16 cents a share but revenue came in light at $424.5 million. The estimate was for 430 million. K.B.
