MCGUIRK: I mean he's going to have to send his jackets to the cleaners after that, I mean, just figuratively, it was sort of nauseating. But --

IMUS: What? There was not any --

MCGUIRK: The way he just -- I mean, did he ask him about the memoir that's coming out? --

IMUS: Oh, no --

MCGUIRK: Memoir --

IMUS: Stewart was jerking his chain.

MCGUIRK: No, he wasn't.

IMUS: Yes, he was.

MCGUIRK: I saw it. He was --

IMUS: He wasn't jerking his chain?

MCGUIRK: Not at all. He was telling him what a great speech you gave and could you put facts out there, unlike Mitt Romney --

IMUS: You're telling me Stewart wasn't kidding with that?

MCGUIRK: No, not at all. That was a straight-up journalistic --

IMUS: Didn't he sound like he was kidding --

BARTLETT: I mean, I didn't see it, so, I mean, I was there?

IMUS: He didn't sound like he was kidding?

POWELL: Little tongue in cheek to me.

IMUS: That's what he sounded, like a little tongue in cheek. Really?

MCGUIRK: No, absolutely not.

IMUS: Well, because you're a hater.

MCGUIRK: No, because I actually watched it, I saw it. Now, let's move on here, boss, because the clock is ticking and I know you want to get Mr. Cavuto on.

MCSHANE: Yes.

MCGUIRK: And we got us a little sex scandal over at "Good Morning America".

IMUS: All right.

MCGUIRK: You know, locally here in New York City, you have this news anchor on "Channel 7", "Wabc" Liz Cho.

IMUS: Oh, my God, that's a home wrecker there.

MCGUIRK: Well, excuse me. She and this dude, Josh Elliott, who's an anchor on "Good Morning America", they're apparently an item. I'm going to read from the "New York Post" --

IMUS: I thought she was married.

MCGUIRK: Well, she was.

IMUS: Oh --

MCGUIRK: This is what the "New York Post" page six writes this morning. "After we revealed yesterday that 41-year-old beauty Cho, the co-anchor of "Wabc TV" in New York, split with her husband and moved out of their Yonkers mansion three months ago.

She insisted through friends that they're just friends. She's 41, he's 41 and they say "That this guy Elliott is a regular visitor to Liz's new apartment on west 90th street, baby.

And he's been spotted leaving the building in the morning. He's even been picked up from Cho's part to head to work at "Good Morning America" where he works as a news anchor.

Good morning Elizabeth. But they insists that the relationship began after she moved out of the Yonkers mansion.

IMUS: OK.

MCGUIRK: Right, it has to be true, right?

RUFINO: All right.

MCGUIRK: Yes, but in any case, you know this guy Josh Elliott, he's sort of in Kris Humphries area, he hosts this unwatchable "Good Afternoon America" show --

IMUS: No, I don't --

MCGUIRK: With Lara Spencer. Well, anyway this is blooming over --

IMUS: Stuff about praising anchor, no, I don't.

MCGUIRK: And they're beating the crap out of the "Today Show" by the way - -

IMUS: Not good, I'm happy about that.

MCSHANE: Yes.

MCGUIRK: Yes.

IMUS: That's all you got?

MCGUIRK: Well, I do have another piece of David Letterman clip, busting on Jay Leno and Mitt Romney, but --

IMUS: No, he's a creep --

MCGUIRK: We can save it.

IMUS: Thirty minutes after the hour, and here, Cavuto is next.

One of Neil's favorite songs.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the Fox Business Network. And now, here is Diane Macedo.

MACEDO: Good morning, everyone. General Motors is recalling more than 426,000 Chevrolet, Pontiac and Saturn sedans in the U.S. due to transmission problems. The recall affects vehicles model years 2007 to 2010.

The automaker says the transmission gear position may not match the gear on the shifter and that could cause the vehicle to move when drivers think they're in park. GM says it's aware of four crashes due to the problem, but no injuries reported as of now.

Meanwhile, the recall news after General Motors announced it has reached an agreement with the Canadian Autoworkers Union over a labor contract. Under the tentative four year deal, GM will add a third shift to its flex line at its Ontario facility.

The automaker had planned to shutdown that plant three-shift consolidated line next June, but will operate with at least one line until June of 2014. The CAW continues to negotiate a deal with Chrysler after it already reached one with Ford earlier in the week.

IMUS IN THE MORNING continues now after we check the weather with Fox 5 meteorologist, Mike Woods.

MIKE WOODS, FOX 5 METEOROLOGIST: Good morning, everyone. Looks like we have some wet weather out there, but not a ton of it for the country here. We've got an area of low pressure still rotating around the Great Lakes, but it's bringing showers from the Upper Midwest and Central Mississippi Valley area.

And then back towards the rest of the Great Lakes over to the east and also a few showers popping up around Florida again, southeast, slightly risky in terms of showers and storms. Tampa, you'll see a few scattered storms and high temp today, 88 degrees.

And Phoenix, no rain for you, sunny skies with a high of 103 and Seattle partly cloudy skies with a high of 63. Sacramento, California, you've got sunny skies there today with a high of 91, still warm. I'm Mike Woods from Fox 5 in New York.

IMUS: All right, it's 36 minutes past the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Please welcome to the program, senior vice president, anchor manager, Fox Business News, Fox NewsChannel, a man who sadly calls himself the financial factor, Neil P. Cavuto. What does the P stand for?

NEIL P. CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS: Patrick.

IMUS: Good morning, Mr. Cavuto.

CAVUTO: Good morning, Mr. Imus.

IMUS: How are you?

CAVUTO: It was scary bumping into you this morning.

IMUS: Well, I had my little oxygen tank with me.

CAVUTO: You kind of looked like Hannibal Lector being driven in on a gurney and I thought, is he up to doing the show today? But here you are, encouragement to all us.

IMUS: Well, anaerobic, but I recover quickly and I don't need oxygen just to sit around and talk.

CAVUTO: I admire that.

IMUS: Happy birthday tomorrow.

CAVUTO: How did you know that?

IMUS: It's my job to know those things.

CAVUTO: Thank you very much.

IMUS: So, you like the Vince Gill interview?

CAVUTO: I liked it very much, I'm a big fan of his and I thought you did a very good job. A lot of people, you know, when you interview stars it's always tough. You do a fawning interview or you do a revealing one particularly like the things about your brother, how tough that is and trying to get a handle on it, very real. I liked it very much.

IMUS: So I asked you off the air if you liked Romney. Do you?

CAVUTO: I do, personally I like him a lot.

IMUS: It doesn't bother you that he's a dope, right?

CAVUTO: He's not a dope.

IMUS: OK, he's not a good campaigner, is he?

CAVUTO: I think that remains to be seen. The election hasn't happened yet.

IMUS: No, sir. Do you think that these leaked videos, these missteps that they've each made, is going to make a difference when people vote?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: You don't?

CAVUTO: I do not. I think in the end, it always is the economy. I think that's what-- we could have extenuating circumstances, the Middle East explosion, could have the impact, but almost every U.S. election is decided by the economy.

How good people feel, how maybe not so good people feel and we're always willing to entertain switching horses mid stream when an incumbent is battling a tough economy, but we've really got to see the other horse.

I think in 1980 when the polls were similarly tight between Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. A lot of people liked Jimmy Carter, frustrated with the economy, but they were more than willing to entertain an alternative and along came Ronald Reagan to appeal to alternative.

IMUS: How many people vote for the person who they like the best?

CAVUTO: I think it plays a part.

IMUS: How big a part?

CAVUTO: Well, I do think it helped George Bush, many polls were done on the debate between he and Al Gore and then later on between he and John Kerry. And I think most people said who won the debates?

And a lot of them said, particularly in 2004, with John Kerry, who do you like more or relate to more? George Bush. I'm not saying that's always the case, but it does help if people feel you're either more approachable or likeable.

And I think in 1960 from the television critics later who said that Richard Nixon was sweating and detached and John Kennedy looked relaxed and smooth. These things on some level do connect for people.

IMUS: Talking with Neil Cavuto -- talking with Neil Cavuto here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. It's 5 until the hour, you know what you ought to do here at Fox?

CAVUTO: What's that?

IMUS: An interesting experiment because my wife mentioned this to me.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: She wants to have sex with you, by the way.

CAVUTO: Who doesn't?

IMUS: I don't. Wants to have sex with you --

CAVUTO: And go ahead.

IMUS: Anyway.

CAVUTO: Come on, Don, tell me. Go ahead, please.

IMUS: Well, I forgot --

CAVUTO: At least say something, you guys.

IMUS: Here is what you should do.

CAVUTO: Like an interview by Rainman.

IMUS: When is the first debate, October 1st?

CAVUTO: I think the 3rd.

IMUS: It's the day he hit the home run. Here is what you should do. Please don't interrupt when I'm talking with Mr. Cavuto, Warner. I'll come over there and beat on you like a rented mule. Just kidding. You should get a group of people.

Frank -- You should do it. Get a group, have them listen to the audio feed and don't let them watch it and have the group just watch it on television and then poll each group to see who won. Who they think won.

CAVUTO: That's not a bad idea.

IMUS: It is a good idea isn't it?

CAVUTO: It's a very good idea.

IMUS: Because Deirdre said to me -- don't you hate it when guys quote their wives. You know, that means they're so p-whipped.

CAVUTO: And she's insane for putting up with you.

IMUS: Absolutely. Because you get distracted who looked and --

CAVUTO: Yes, yes. And history bears that out. I mean, people who, I guess, were listened in to the Nixon-Kennedy debate thought Nixon, and Bush and Al Gore. That was a little more debatable than Kerry and Bush.

IMUS: Should I call Roger and --

CAVUTO: Please do, please do. I'm not going to act on this because I actually think the idea is silly.

IMUS: Do you really?

CAVUTO: Yes. I do.

IMUS: You do?

CAVUTO: I think 90 percent of people are going to be watching and not listening.

IMUS: Well, you're just, I don't know, you're just -- I don't know.

CAVUTO: Well, I just, I think in 1960, it would have been a brilliant idea, but last time I checked --

IMUS: It's a good idea now just to see. It's 18 until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Did you read "Killing Lincoln?"

CAVUTO: I did read it. It's a great book.

IMUS: But I'll tell you what is a terrific book "Killing Kennedy."

CAVUTO: I haven't -- I know it's out or will be out, but-- I really enjoyed "Killing Lincoln", the way he built it up and x number of days to live and I thought when I first opened it, we know what happened in the end.

But he didn't do a great job and see what the Kennedy book, but I think he's got -- he could a series on his hands. I don't know how you handle Philmore, getting Philmore, but --

IMUS: It's enormously entertaining and there's no heavy lifting, not a --

CAVUTO: I think it's a very good point. A lot of the stories, Brinkley, I love dearly and Harry Truman, 900 pages on and on and all great, but you can make this fun and engaging.

IMUS: And accessible.

CAVUTO: It's a way to do it. I didn't see the kids' version that's out but --

IMUS: That's pretty good, too. It's pretty good, too, so, do you think he writes any of it.

CAVUTO: I think he does.

IMUS: What's --

CAVUTO: -- his show.

IMUS: That doesn't make any difference.

CAVUTO: No, it doesn't, but when you say does he write his stuff? Of course, he writes his stuff.

IMUS: How is that demeaning --

CAVUTO: You say does he write the book.

IMUS: As a journalist, I have a --

CAVUTO: Excuse me? Excuse me.

IMUS: It's 17 until the hour here in the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Are you a sports fan?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: Not at all.

CAVUTO: I heard you guys go through the Sunday games. I guess these are football games? Terrific, no offense guns and Warner but --

IMUS: That's fine, but do you ever watch sports on television?

CAVUTO: I have the attention span of a gnat. I watch the highlights. I said, why can't the games be like the highlights?

IMUS: Do you ever watch Sports Center?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: Where do you get the highlights?

CAVUTO: Passing around the news or online, but I'm not really -- I'm afraid I'm not really into it.

IMUS: So, do you watch television?

CAVUTO: I know this is going to sound elitist, but I really don't. I'm just, it's not --

IMUS: Mr. Cavuto --

CAVUTO: I watch you, of course, I mean, that's a staple. Connell and Dagen and flip over --

IMUS: Mr. Cavuto is on at 4 in the afternoon on the Fox NewsChannel and 8 p.m. and do you think that --

CAVUTO: I want to come back at you with anger, but I saw you with the oxygen tank and go lightly no need to be mean.

IMUS: It's a quarter until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

CAVUTO: This is three times in this hour with this interview, you relay the time. It's always fascinating to me why you do that.

IMUS: I'm doing a radio program.

CAVUTO: I know that. I know, but -- like I say there are clocks in those cars, right?

IMUS: I can stop giving the time.

CAVUTO: OK, more time for me.

IMUS: Bernie, put a call in to Bob -- anyway do you think Obama is a socialist?

CAVUTO: No. I think he likes big government. I think he likes more big government and espouses the view much like FDR in 1932, government the only way to get us out of the mess and a lot more people are beholden to the government as a result of that.

And he's got a pretty good base of people who would vote for him as a result and I think that probably was what Mitt Romney was inelegantly getting at. But we all remember, you know, but FDR got re-elected in a landslide in 36 even though the economy still, still was pretty bad.

IMUS: As ours does.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: And you would think that one of the things that Romney could get some traction and I think, that you asked, I think --

CAVUTO: Your thoughts are very valuable to me.

IMUS: I think the day that Romney gets elected, the economy is better just by -- he doesn't have to do anything, do you agree with that?

CAVUTO: Well, you have to do something. You're popping up in a different --

IMUS: That wasn't the question.

CAVUTO: You mean, well, it's a stupid point. Sounds like Godzilla, January 20th just by virtue of being Godzilla being in the office because it's not Barack Obama, things are better.

IMUS: If it makes you feel like a bigger person, which you're --

CAVUTO: OK, you know, I could lose weight, you will always be evil.

IMUS: To make me feel bad by calling me a list of names, but don't you think the way the markets would react --

CAVUTO: It's always fine until --

IMUS: And the financial community.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: That the things would, people would feel better and I know he has do something, your suit dummy candidate and mine, but wouldn't have to do anything, but just get elected and it would be better. Do you think that's true?

CAVUTO: I don't, I don't, obviously if the nation turns to the challenger to throw the incumbent out of office. It's hoping what you said. And remember, electing Ronald Reagan in a landslide didn't bring results, in fact, the recession many more years and jobs lost until we had to boom in '82.

Coming out of that so things take time, I'm not subscribing to the screw that automatically things are better. They're ready to do well if we don't keep what we're doing and stop with a new guy in there. But you have to do stuff.

You have to put up some initiatives that will change the direction. Ronald Reagan did, and you know, the question would be for Romney administration, if it were to happen, whether it would.

IMUS: Is there a way now to know -- is there a way for you to know who will win the election?

CAVUTO: I have no idea.

IMUS: Do you have a gut sense?

CAVUTO: I do, but I'm not going to share that with you. I will say this - -

IMUS: You're really a creep.

CAVUTO: That's lovely. I only relate this to you. I think I told you this before. When I went to Wisconsin to cover the recall election, polls going into that weekend had dead even. I think it had it dead even and we know at that Walker won by six points.

Now, I had a theory and I could be very wrong that conservative support is understated in some of the state polls, maybe with unwinding a bit it's beyond the margin of error, but I do think these states apparently Mitt Romney is going to get blown out in, I don't subscribe to that.

IMUS: You're going to get to the point eventually, right?

CAVUTO: I just told you. And I think the polls in the battle ground state understate Romney's support.

IMUS: Hope you're right.

CAVUTO: And when you say Romney's my man you always say that.

IMUS: Yes.

CAVUTO: But then you disparage him.

IMUS: Keeping it real.

CAVUTO: And for every wonderful interview like Vince Gill and then you do one like you did with Frank Rich.

IMUS: My job is to keep it real, right, Bernie?

CAVUTO: Frank Rich interview, just kept it real.

IMUS: Keeping it real.

CAVUTO: OK.

IMUS: Thank you very much for --

CAVUTO: This is it?

IMUS: You were on for 12 minutes.

CAVUTO: That's 12 minutes of my life. I'm never getting back.

IMUS: And so does the audience.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACEOD: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. Let's take a look at the markets. In Europe, the "Financial Times" is reporting that European Union authorities are working with the Spanish government to come up with a bailout plan and unlimited bond buying by the European Central Bank.

Markets there are now mixed with London down by about 5 points. Paris is up 10 and Frankfort is up about 64. Here in the U.S., we have seen green arrows across the board all morning. Dow futures are up by 56. The S&P is up by about 5 and the Nasdaq is up by 13.

Now that Apple's iPhone is available, we're also finding out exactly what makes the smartphone work. The repair firm fix it, got one open and chips from Qualcomm, Avago Technologies and Skyworks Solution.

The iPhone also includes an audio chip made by Cirrus Logic and its gyroscope, which is used to track its orientation was made by ST Microelectronics. Keep an eye on those stocks and those are the companies that didn't participate in the iPhone to see the reaction today.

The world's biggest retailer is looking to do business in India. The "Wall Street Journal" reports Wal-Mart hopes to open its first stores in the country within two years. That move comes after the government last week agreed to allow international supermarket chains to enter India through joint ventures.

Wal-Mart says it hadn't decided yet where or how many stores it would like to have, but the company expects to continue its current partnerships with barky enterprises of India, a chain of 17 cash and carry stores.

Here's a look at commodities, oil and gold are up. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on Fox Business.

(IMUS EXTRA SEGMENTS)

END

urn:contentItem:56MJ-0Y11-JB20-G49Y-00000-00Apple's iPhone 5 Hitting Store Shelves Around the World; McDonalds, Texas Instruments and Covidien Raise Quarterly Dividends; General Motors Reaches Labor Deal with Canadian Auto Workers; WSJ: Wal-Mart Hopes to Open First Store in India Within Two Years2012-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisIMUS IN THE MORNING6:00 AM ESTJosh Raymond, Juan WilliamsNEWSBusiness092101cb.220Apple's iPhone 5 Hitting Store Shelves Around the World; McDonalds, Texas Instruments and Covidien Raise Quarterly Dividends; General Motors Reaches Labor Deal with Canadian Auto Workers; WSJ: Wal-Mart Hopes to Open First Store in India Within Two YearsDon Imus, Diane Macedo, Robert Gray, Connell McShane, Warner Wolf, Dagen McDowell, Bernard McGuirk, Mike Woods, Lou Rufino, Rob Bartlett, Tony Powell, Carley Shimkus

DON IMUS, HOST, "IMUS IN THE MORNING": This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the FOX Business Network. Now, here's Diane Macedo.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning, everyone. IMUS: You know, I never thought about it, about women's hair thinning. I thought only men got bald until I saw a bald-headed woman. And you do not want that in your house, a bald-headed woman, that is not good.

MCSHANE: No.

IMUS: Well, you can fix that though, because from Chamonix, a good outfit you can trust them.

They offer a money-back guarantee of all of their products, the Esotique, the T-Gen, the Heart Factors Plus.

They now have this stuff, this serum called ProVia, p-r-o-v-i-a, it's all natural hair serum from Chamonix, a money-back guarantee, you rub this in your gored there for two or three weeks and whatever.

And your hair is going to get thicker and will look better. So it's not falling on the floor there, you don't need that. So, call 800-754-6980.

ProVia fights follicle aging and improves scalp microcirculation all at the same time. It is guaranteed to work, if you will call now, they'll throw in a free month supply of this stuff.

Or you could rub it on your hair until you make yourself insane. 800-754- 6980, call and get it.

MACEDO: Hi, everyone, I'm Diane Macedo. And more companies are rewarding their shareholders with higher quarterly dividends. McDonald's is hacking its quarterly pay-off by 10 percent to 77 cents a share.

Texas Instruments is boosting its dividend by 24 percent to 21 cents a share. And Covidien is increasing its quarterly dividend by 16 percent to 26 cents a share.

Taking a look at Futures now, we're seeing green arrows across the board, IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on Fox Business.

WOLF: The Giants have now dropped. They were a one point favorite, now the four regulars are out. Carolina is a one point favorite.

IMUS: Oh.

WOLF: Here was Cam Newton on tonight's game.

(BEGIN AUDIO CLIP)

CAM NEWTON, QUARTERBACK, CAROLINA PANTHERS: I'm a football player at the end of the day. If they want me to run, I'll run, if they want me to throw, I'll throw.

If they want me to block, I'm going to block, if they want me to go get some water to better the team, I'm going to do it.

(END AUDIO CLIP)

IMUS: I wonder what he is at the beginning of the day?

MCSHANE: Yes.

TONY POWELL, IMUS IN THE MORNING: Or cares about the mid part of the day.

IMUS: Or at noon.

POWELL: Yes.

IMUS: Or the middle part of that day.

WOLF: That's a good question.

IMUS: At the end of the day --

WOLF: That's right.

IMUS: He's a football player.

(LAUGHTER)

So, what is he at the beginning of the day, a runway model?

WOLF: That's good.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: It is 25 after the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, this portion of the program is sponsored by My Pillow, the official online sponsor of "Wabc Radio".

Enter a promo code Imus for your 25 percent discount and these fools are giving this stuff away.

All right, time for a Bernie briefing here now, and with that is Bernard McGuirk. Good morning Mr. McGuirk.

MCGUIRK: Good morning, Mr. Imus. And the big dawg Bill Clinton was on with your friend Jon Stewart last night and he was boring, he was just flat-out.

He made Charlie Rose sound like Mad Dog Russo, he was so boring. But, listen to Jon Stewart do his best impersonation of Monica Lewinsky journalistically.

(BEGIN AUDIO CLIP)

JON STEWART, COMEDIAN & TELEVISION HOST: Give any good speeches lately or? How was that -- how did that feel at the convention?

Could you tell that you were crushing it as you were doing it? Did you, did you feel that?

BILL CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Yes and no. But -- because I didn't want to talk down to people, I wanted to explain what I thought was going on.

STEWART: That's what was so stunning, I think. That's why it was such a bracing speech. The phrase you mentioned earlier about getting the facts right, and they would have -- you would attach numbers to them that were real.

(LAUGHTER)

I thought it was a bold choice on your part.

(END AUDIO CLIP)

MCGUIRK: I mean he's going to have to send his jackets to the cleaners after that, I mean, just figuratively, it was sort of nauseating. But --

IMUS: What? There was not any --

MCGUIRK: The way he just -- I mean, did he ask him about the memoir that's coming out? --

IMUS: Oh, no --

MCGUIRK: Memoir --

IMUS: Stewart was jerking his chain.

MCGUIRK: No, he wasn't.

IMUS: Yes, he was.

MCGUIRK: I saw it. He was --

IMUS: He wasn't jerking his chain?

MCGUIRK: Not at all. He was telling him what a great speech you gave and could you put facts out there, unlike Mitt Romney --

IMUS: You're telling me Stewart wasn't kidding with that?

MCGUIRK: No, not at all. That was a straight-up journalistic --

IMUS: Didn't he sound like he was kidding --

BARTLETT: I mean, I didn't see it, so, I mean, I was there?

IMUS: He didn't sound like he was kidding?

POWELL: Little tongue in cheek to me.

IMUS: That's what he sounded, like a little tongue in cheek. Really?

MCGUIRK: No, absolutely not.

IMUS: Well, because you're a hater.

MCGUIRK: No, because I actually watched it, I saw it. Now, let's move on here, boss, because the clock is ticking and I know you want to get Mr. Cavuto on.

MCSHANE: Yes.

MCGUIRK: And we got us a little sex scandal over at "Good Morning America".

IMUS: All right.

MCGUIRK: You know, locally here in New York City, you have this news anchor on "Channel 7", "Wabc" Liz Cho.

IMUS: Oh, my God, that's a home wrecker there.

MCGUIRK: Well, excuse me. She and this dude, Josh Elliott, who's an anchor on "Good Morning America", they're apparently an item. I'm going to read from the "New York Post" --

IMUS: I thought she was married.

MCGUIRK: Well, she was.

IMUS: Oh --

MCGUIRK: This is what the "New York Post" page six writes this morning. "After we revealed yesterday that 41-year-old beauty Cho, the co-anchor of "Wabc TV" in New York, split with her husband and moved out of their Yonkers mansion three months ago.

She insisted through friends that they're just friends. She's 41, he's 41 and they say "That this guy Elliott is a regular visitor to Liz's new apartment on west 90th street, baby.

And he's been spotted leaving the building in the morning. He's even been picked up from Cho's part to head to work at "Good Morning America" where he works as a news anchor.

Good morning Elizabeth. But they insists that the relationship began after she moved out of the Yonkers mansion.

IMUS: OK.

MCGUIRK: Right, it has to be true, right?

RUFINO: All right.

MCGUIRK: Yes, but in any case, you know this guy Josh Elliott, he's sort of in Kris Humphries area, he hosts this unwatchable "Good Afternoon America" show --

IMUS: No, I don't --

MCGUIRK: With Lara Spencer. Well, anyway this is blooming over --

IMUS: Stuff about praising anchor, no, I don't.

MCGUIRK: And they're beating the crap out of the "Today Show" by the way - -

IMUS: Not good, I'm happy about that.

MCSHANE: Yes.

MCGUIRK: Yes.

IMUS: That's all you got?

MCGUIRK: Well, I do have another piece of David Letterman clip, busting on Jay Leno and Mitt Romney, but --

IMUS: No, he's a creep --

MCGUIRK: We can save it.

IMUS: Thirty minutes after the hour, and here, Cavuto is next.

One of Neil's favorite songs.

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the Fox Business Network. And now, here is Diane Macedo.

MACEDO: Good morning, everyone. General Motors is recalling more than 426,000 Chevrolet, Pontiac and Saturn sedans in the U.S. due to transmission problems. The recall affects vehicles model years 2007 to 2010.

The automaker says the transmission gear position may not match the gear on the shifter and that could cause the vehicle to move when drivers think they're in park. GM says it's aware of four crashes due to the problem, but no injuries reported as of now.

Meanwhile, the recall news after General Motors announced it has reached an agreement with the Canadian Autoworkers Union over a labor contract. Under the tentative four year deal, GM will add a third shift to its flex line at its Ontario facility.

The automaker had planned to shutdown that plant three-shift consolidated line next June, but will operate with at least one line until June of 2014. The CAW continues to negotiate a deal with Chrysler after it already reached one with Ford earlier in the week.

IMUS IN THE MORNING continues now after we check the weather with Fox 5 meteorologist, Mike Woods.

MIKE WOODS, FOX 5 METEOROLOGIST: Good morning, everyone. Looks like we have some wet weather out there, but not a ton of it for the country here. We've got an area of low pressure still rotating around the Great Lakes, but it's bringing showers from the Upper Midwest and Central Mississippi Valley area.

And then back towards the rest of the Great Lakes over to the east and also a few showers popping up around Florida again, southeast, slightly risky in terms of showers and storms. Tampa, you'll see a few scattered storms and high temp today, 88 degrees.

And Phoenix, no rain for you, sunny skies with a high of 103 and Seattle partly cloudy skies with a high of 63. Sacramento, California, you've got sunny skies there today with a high of 91, still warm. I'm Mike Woods from Fox 5 in New York.

IMUS: All right, it's 36 minutes past the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Please welcome to the program, senior vice president, anchor manager, Fox Business News, Fox News Channel, a man who sadly calls himself the financial factor, Neil P. Cavuto. What does the P stand for?

NEIL P. CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS: Patrick.

IMUS: Good morning, Mr. Cavuto.

CAVUTO: Good morning, Mr. Imus.

IMUS: How are you?

CAVUTO: It was scary bumping into you this morning.

IMUS: Well, I had my little oxygen tank with me.

CAVUTO: You kind of looked like Hannibal Lector being driven in on a gurney and I thought, is he up to doing the show today? But here you are, encouragement to all us.

IMUS: Well, anaerobic, but I recover quickly and I don't need oxygen just to sit around and talk.

CAVUTO: I admire that.

IMUS: Happy birthday tomorrow.

CAVUTO: How did you know that?

IMUS: It's my job to know those things.

CAVUTO: Thank you very much.

IMUS: So, you like the Vince Gill interview?

CAVUTO: I liked it very much, I'm a big fan of his and I thought you did a very good job. A lot of people, you know, when you interview stars it's always tough. You do a fawning interview or you do a revealing one particularly like the things about your brother, how tough that is and trying to get a handle on it, very real. I liked it very much.

IMUS: So I asked you off the air if you liked Romney. Do you?

CAVUTO: I do, personally I like him a lot.

IMUS: It doesn't bother you that he's a dope, right?

CAVUTO: He's not a dope.

IMUS: OK, he's not a good campaigner, is he?

CAVUTO: I think that remains to be seen. The election hasn't happened yet.

IMUS: No, sir. Do you think that these leaked videos, these missteps that they've each made, is going to make a difference when people vote?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: You don't?

CAVUTO: I do not. I think in the end, it always is the economy. I think that's what-- we could have extenuating circumstances, the Middle East explosion, could have the impact, but almost every U.S. election is decided by the economy.

How good people feel, how maybe not so good people feel and we're always willing to entertain switching horses mid stream when an incumbent is battling a tough economy, but we've really got to see the other horse.

I think in 1980 when the polls were similarly tight between Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. A lot of people liked Jimmy Carter, frustrated with the economy, but they were more than willing to entertain an alternative and along came Ronald Reagan to appeal to alternative.

IMUS: How many people vote for the person who they like the best?

CAVUTO: I think it plays a part.

IMUS: How big a part?

CAVUTO: Well, I do think it helped George Bush, many polls were done on the debate between he and Al Gore and then later on between he and John Kerry. And I think most people said who won the debates?

And a lot of them said, particularly in 2004, with John Kerry, who do you like more or relate to more? George Bush. I'm not saying that's always the case, but it does help if people feel you're either more approachable or likeable.

And I think in 1960 from the television critics later who said that Richard Nixon was sweating and detached and John Kennedy looked relaxed and smooth. These things on some level do connect for people.

IMUS: Talking with Neil Cavuto -- talking with Neil Cavuto here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. It's 5 until the hour, you know what you ought to do here at Fox?

CAVUTO: What's that?

IMUS: An interesting experiment because my wife mentioned this to me.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: She wants to have sex with you, by the way.

CAVUTO: Who doesn't?

IMUS: I don't. Wants to have sex with you --

CAVUTO: And go ahead.

IMUS: Anyway.

CAVUTO: Come on, Don, tell me. Go ahead, please.

IMUS: Well, I forgot --

CAVUTO: At least say something, you guys.

IMUS: Here is what you should do.

CAVUTO: Like an interview by Rainman.

IMUS: When is the first debate, October 1st?

CAVUTO: I think the 3rd.

IMUS: It's the day he hit the home run. Here is what you should do. Please don't interrupt when I'm talking with Mr. Cavuto, Warner. I'll come over there and beat on you like a rented mule. Just kidding. You should get a group of people.

Frank -- You should do it. Get a group, have them listen to the audio feed and don't let them watch it and have the group just watch it on television and then poll each group to see who won. Who they think won.

CAVUTO: That's not a bad idea.

IMUS: It is a good idea isn't it?

CAVUTO: It's a very good idea.

IMUS: Because Deirdre said to me -- don't you hate it when guys quote their wives. You know, that means they're so p-whipped.

CAVUTO: And she's insane for putting up with you.

IMUS: Absolutely. Because you get distracted who looked and --

CAVUTO: Yes, yes. And history bears that out. I mean, people who, I guess, were listened in to the Nixon-Kennedy debate thought Nixon, and Bush and Al Gore. That was a little more debatable than Kerry and Bush.

IMUS: Should I call Roger and --

CAVUTO: Please do, please do. I'm not going to act on this because I actually think the idea is silly.

IMUS: Do you really?

CAVUTO: Yes. I do.

IMUS: You do?

CAVUTO: I think 90 percent of people are going to be watching and not listening.

IMUS: Well, you're just, I don't know, you're just -- I don't know.

CAVUTO: Well, I just, I think in 1960, it would have been a brilliant idea, but last time I checked --

IMUS: It's a good idea now just to see. It's 18 until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Did you read "Killing Lincoln?"

CAVUTO: I did read it. It's a great book.

IMUS: But I'll tell you what is a terrific book "Killing Kennedy."

CAVUTO: I haven't -- I know it's out or will be out, but-- I really enjoyed "Killing Lincoln", the way he built it up and x number of days to live and I thought when I first opened it, we know what happened in the end.

But he didn't do a great job and see what the Kennedy book, but I think he's got -- he could a series on his hands. I don't know how you handle Philmore, getting Philmore, but --

IMUS: It's enormously entertaining and there's no heavy lifting, not a --

CAVUTO: I think it's a very good point. A lot of the stories, Brinkley, I love dearly and Harry Truman, 900 pages on and on and all great, but you can make this fun and engaging.

IMUS: And accessible.

CAVUTO: It's a way to do it. I didn't see the kids' version that's out but --

IMUS: That's pretty good, too. It's pretty good, too, so, do you think he writes any of it.

CAVUTO: I think he does.

IMUS: What's --

CAVUTO: -- his show.

IMUS: That doesn't make any difference.

CAVUTO: No, it doesn't, but when you say does he write his stuff? Of course, he writes his stuff.

IMUS: How is that demeaning --

CAVUTO: You say does he write the book.

IMUS: As a journalist, I have a --

CAVUTO: Excuse me? Excuse me.

IMUS: It's 17 until the hour here in the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Are you a sports fan?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: Not at all.

CAVUTO: I heard you guys go through the Sunday games. I guess these are football games? Terrific, no offense guns and Warner but --

IMUS: That's fine, but do you ever watch sports on television?

CAVUTO: I have the attention span of a gnat. I watch the highlights. I said, why can't the games be like the highlights?

IMUS: Do you ever watch Sports Center?

CAVUTO: No.

IMUS: Where do you get the highlights?

CAVUTO: Passing around the news or online, but I'm not really -- I'm afraid I'm not really into it.

IMUS: So, do you watch television?

CAVUTO: I know this is going to sound elitist, but I really don't. I'm just, it's not --

IMUS: Mr. Cavuto --

CAVUTO: I watch you, of course, I mean, that's a staple. Connell and Dagen and flip over --

IMUS: Mr. Cavuto is on at 4 in the afternoon on the Fox News Channel and 8 p.m. and do you think that --

CAVUTO: I want to come back at you with anger, but I saw you with the oxygen tank and go lightly no need to be mean.

IMUS: It's a quarter until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

CAVUTO: This is three times in this hour with this interview, you relay the time. It's always fascinating to me why you do that.

IMUS: I'm doing a radio program.

CAVUTO: I know that. I know, but -- like I say there are clocks in those cars, right?

IMUS: I can stop giving the time.

CAVUTO: OK, more time for me.

IMUS: Bernie, put a call in to Bob -- anyway do you think Obama is a socialist?

CAVUTO: No. I think he likes big government. I think he likes more big government and espouses the view much like FDR in 1932, government the only way to get us out of the mess and a lot more people are beholden to the government as a result of that.

And he's got a pretty good base of people who would vote for him as a result and I think that probably was what Mitt Romney was inelegantly getting at. But we all remember, you know, but FDR got re-elected in a landslide in 36 even though the economy still, still was pretty bad.

IMUS: As ours does.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: And you would think that one of the things that Romney could get some traction and I think, that you asked, I think --

CAVUTO: Your thoughts are very valuable to me.

IMUS: I think the day that Romney gets elected, the economy is better just by -- he doesn't have to do anything, do you agree with that?

CAVUTO: Well, you have to do something. You're popping up in a different --

IMUS: That wasn't the question.

CAVUTO: You mean, well, it's a stupid point. Sounds like Godzilla, January 20th just by virtue of being Godzilla being in the office because it's not Barack Obama, things are better.

IMUS: If it makes you feel like a bigger person, which you're --

CAVUTO: OK, you know, I could lose weight, you will always be evil.

IMUS: To make me feel bad by calling me a list of names, but don't you think the way the markets would react --

CAVUTO: It's always fine until --

IMUS: And the financial community.

CAVUTO: Yes.

IMUS: That the things would, people would feel better and I know he has do something, your suit dummy candidate and mine, but wouldn't have to do anything, but just get elected and it would be better. Do you think that's true?

CAVUTO: I don't, I don't, obviously if the nation turns to the challenger to throw the incumbent out of office. It's hoping what you said. And remember, electing Ronald Reagan in a landslide didn't bring results, in fact, the recession many more years and jobs lost until we had to boom in `82.

Coming out of that so things take time, I'm not subscribing to the screw that automatically things are better. They're ready to do well if we don't keep what we're doing and stop with a new guy in there. But you have to do stuff.

You have to put up some initiatives that will change the direction. Ronald Reagan did, and you know, the question would be for Romney administration, if it were to happen, whether it would.

IMUS: Is there a way now to know -- is there a way for you to know who will win the election?

CAVUTO: I have no idea.

IMUS: Do you have a gut sense?

CAVUTO: I do, but I'm not going to share that with you. I will say this - -

IMUS: You're really a creep.

CAVUTO: That's lovely. I only relate this to you. I think I told you this before. When I went to Wisconsin to cover the recall election, polls going into that weekend had dead even. I think it had it dead even and we know at that Walker won by six points.

Now, I had a theory and I could be very wrong that conservative support is understated in some of the state polls, maybe with unwinding a bit it's beyond the margin of error, but I do think these states apparently Mitt Romney is going to get blown out in, I don't subscribe to that.

IMUS: You're going to get to the point eventually, right?

CAVUTO: I just told you. And I think the polls in the battle ground state understate Romney's support.

IMUS: Hope you're right.

CAVUTO: And when you say Romney's my man you always say that.

IMUS: Yes.

CAVUTO: But then you disparage him.

IMUS: Keeping it real.

CAVUTO: And for every wonderful interview like Vince Gill and then you do one like you did with Frank Rich.

IMUS: My job is to keep it real, right, Bernie?

CAVUTO: Frank Rich interview, just kept it real.

IMUS: Keeping it real.

CAVUTO: OK.

IMUS: Thank you very much for --

CAVUTO: This is it?

IMUS: You were on for 12 minutes.

CAVUTO: That's 12 minutes of my life. I'm never getting back.

IMUS: And so does the audience.

MACEOD: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. Let's take a look at the markets. In Europe, the "Financial Times" is reporting that European Union authorities are working with the Spanish government to come up with a bailout plan and unlimited bond buying by the European Central Bank.

Markets there are now mixed with London down by about 5 points. Paris is up 10 and Frankfort is up about 64. Here in the U.S., we have seen green arrows across the board all morning. Dow futures are up by 56. The S&P is up by about 5 and the Nasdaq is up by 13.

Now that Apple's iPhone is available, we're also finding out exactly what makes the smartphone work. The repair firm fix it, got one open and chips from Qualcomm, Avago Technologies and Skyworks Solution.

The iPhone also includes an audio chip made by Cirrus Logic and its gyroscope, which is used to track its orientation was made by ST Microelectronics. Keep an eye on those stocks and those are the companies that didn't participate in the iPhone to see the reaction today.

The world's biggest retailer is looking to do business in India. The "Wall Street Journal" reports Wal-Mart hopes to open its first stores in the country within two years. That move comes after the government last week agreed to allow international supermarket chains to enter India through joint ventures.

Wal-Mart says it hadn't decided yet where or how many stores it would like to have, but the company expects to continue its current partnerships with barky enterprises of India, a chain of 17 cash and carry stores.

Here's a look at commodities, oil and gold are up. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on Fox Business.

(IMUS EXTRA SEGMENTS)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VRR-VHM1-DYS1-02J6-00000-00Apple's latest new market plans should worry us all2019-03-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisFINANCEPg. 1Apple's latest new market plans should worry us allKarlin Lillington

The signature look for an Apple Store, whether in Palo Alto, New York or London, is a variation on the theme of a floor-to-ceiling glass box through which customers can be watched as they browse and interact with the Apple products. Perhaps a different corporate visual metaphor than one encapsulating exposed scrutiny would now be a wiser design choice.

Apple's planned movement into broad new market areas, announced on Monday, and made ever so acceptable by a gushing lineup of A-list celebrities such as Oprah and Steven Spielberg, reveals the company as yet another tech monolith aiming to be our interface point with life.

Apple's new market-expansion ventures this week - games, television and news subscriptions and a credit card - will bring it further into the same controlling space Amazon, Facebook and Google are staking out, where consumers increasingly cede parts of their lives that had remained disparate and uncollated into a single corporate activity and data silo.

They will see more points at which consumers enter the Apple ecosystem, and more opportunities for scrutiny, analysis, and further market expansions.

All this is done in the name of access and convenience for consumers, but this masks the effects on consumer autonomy and privacy, as well as the further distancing of the producers of content from the people who consume it, making it more difficult for people or a multitude of businesses to exist independently of tech company control.

This plan to place more people and more product and service interactions inside the glass box presided over by Apple should worry us all. While some commentators noted Apple would be the privacy champion amongst its big tech rivals, that's only because Apple still manages to get away with presenting itself as tech's privacy and data collection good guy.

 On the plus side - at least so far - that data-respecting version of Apple is what we see in North America and Europe, where chief executive Tim Cook has made a point of contrasting how Apple gathers and manages user data with what rivals such as Facebook, Google and Amazon do. And the company is to be lauded on that point.

Surveillance state

No doubt this perception will be used as a major selling point for Apple's services as it rolls them out, whatever they may ultimately be, on a timeline that we still mostly don't know, because details were so thin on the ground at the big launch event. However, if you are in a market where a well-developed surveillance state maintains tight control on its population, and the state decides to link access to their market with ceding storage of user data to a state-run company, well, hey: Apple is cool with that. They did just

that last year in China

.

This so alarmed press advocacy group Reporters Without Borders that they urged journalists who were China-based iCloud users to either change the country associated with their account (which non-Chinese residents can do) or to get off Apple and iCloud.

Apple's compliance with Chinese state demands was criticised by many human rights and privacy advocacy groups, including Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International.

Apple's willingness to compromise elsewhere signals clearly that it does not draw any hard-and-fast privacy line in the sand and is a sharp reminder that its stronger privacy stance in some markets hinges on corporate whim. What Apple does today may not be what Apple does tomorrow.

 Which brings us back to the real concern here. Slowly, bit by literal bit, we are handing over elements of our lives that range from banking to entertainment, communication to household management, travel to personal health, media control to advertising - and all the sweeping, sensitive data gathering that that involves, exposing us at the most intimate level - to five companies: Amazon, Apple, Google, Facebook, Microsoft.

As tech companies, all come under less regulation than do companies in many of the sectors they have moved into. Much of what they do, as well as how they do it, and why, remains veiled because oversight lags behind their activities and their technologies. We also fail to see how bizarre it is for, say, Apple to offer a credit card because tech company (over)reach is now normalised.

Imagine if, say, Mastercard or McDonald's mediated our online searches, the ads we see, and our household thermostats, tracked where we go each day on maps and mobiles, gathered data from our apps, machine-read our emails, and recorded what programmes we watched and music we listened to. All this is just part of some of the daily intake across the Big Five. Instead, we are directed: Look over there! Toward what Spielberg might produce for a streaming service! Or to 3D augmented reality incorporated into maps! Or to ordering pizza by talking to Alexa!

We, our governments and our regulators need to start paying more attention to the activities of the ringmasters rather than their distracting acts.

urn:contentItem:60VN-JJ61-F07F-82MR-00000-00Apple’s Late To The Connectivity, Fitness And Services Parties – Will It Catch Up?2020-09-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisNEWSApple’s Late To The Connectivity, Fitness And Services Parties – Will It Catch Up?

No iPhone 12 – but pretty much everything else. The question for Apple is: Will the slew of offerings announced this week be enough to bring new users into its ever-expanding ecosystem, and also keep current consumers, well, consuming? On Tuesday (Sept. 15... No iPhone 12 – but pretty much everything else. The question for Apple is:...

No iPhone 12 – but pretty much everything else. The question for Apple is: Will the slew of offerings announced this week be enough to bring new users into its ever-expanding ecosystem, and also keep current consumers, well, consuming? On Tuesday (Sept. 15...

No iPhone 12 – but pretty much everything else. The question for Apple is: Will the slew of offerings announced this week be enough to bring new users into its ever-expanding ecosystem, and also keep current consumers, well, consuming? On Tuesday (Sept. 15), Apple unveiled a slew of watches and services in a bid to give a tailwind to hardware sales and boost its services business. We saw announcements tied to the Apple Watch Series 6, the Apple Watch SE, bundles tied to Apple One and the Apple Fitness+. At a high level, the Apple event underscored the convergence of devices and a wide range of services to be consumed over those devices – centering in this case on health, music and connectivity in general (and some operating system updates). Perhaps no surprise, in the age of the pandemic, is the health pitch. The Apple Watch can help monitor blood oxygen levels and cardio fitness. But beyond that, it is important to note that Apple seems to be positioning the watch as a standalone lure to consumers. Because now, the (two) new watches need not be connected to iPhones to do what they do. A new feature called Family Setup can give users of new generations of watches access to phone calls and texting features via the watch – without being tethered to the phone. Call it a launching pad into the ecosystem, giving simplified hardware everyday functionality that can conceivably be used for cross-selling and upselling. To get a sense of how Apple might be positioning the Series 6 and Apple Watch SE watches, a feature called Schooltime allows parents to restrict access to apps across the devices – which would conceivably keep kids from fiddling around while virtual Zoom classes are in session. Virtual money can be loaded onto the watch, which can be spent via Apple Pay . We note that the Apple Pay feature may be a way to get younger users more adept at using the digital wallet service. It could use the torque. During the fourth quarter of last year, PYMNTS surveyed 1,000 U.S. consumers and found that although 81 percent of adult Americans owned smartphones, just 6 percent used Apple Pay at a physical store five years after the service debuted in 2014. Apple Pay accounted for only about 1.1 percent of all retail and food services sales, excluding online and auto. The rise in contactless payments has undoubtedly moved the needle a bit, but Apple Pay could hardly be called world-beating. And the rise of contactless payments seems connected to card payments, not necessarily digital wallets. In at least one other bid to boost payments, the new operating system iOS 14 offers support for App Clips via NFC, which allows iPhone users to take advantage of “mini” apps – and also enables Apple Pay. That means users don’t have to offer card details when they make purchases, as NFC World reported . There was also the launch of Apple’s fitness service, to be accessed through an app, and which serves up workout videos across iPhones and iPads and can be synced to the watch. It’ a shot across at least part of the bow at firms like Peloton , which also offers fitness content, but the similarity and competition end there. Peloton, of course, has its own ecosystem, tied to its bikes. And the fitness firms, in the midst of the pandemic, may have already scored some of the lowest-hanging fruit by pivoting to in-home classes. Bundling Up Apple One got some play yesterday, where three options offer a range of subscriptions spanning news, fitness and music. But here lies a bit of turbulence. Spotify said on Tuesday (Sept. 15) that the bundles are allegedly more evidence of abuse of dominant market position. A Spotify statement reported by Apple Insider contended that Apple favors its own services. The tech giant is, of course, embroiled in a lawsuit with Epic Games over App Store competition (and is being investigated in the EU over Apple Pay and App Store practices). Apple is pushing its bundling at a time when competition is increasing across media, music and games – and may get at least some restriction from regulators on how content is displayed and promoted across its digital conduits. It’s also a way to make sure subscribers stick around, even if they don’t consume everything that’s offered (in bundles, “strong” content can help prop up “weaker” offerings). In an interview with Karen Webster, Brian Bogosian , CEO at sticky.io, an integrated eCommerce subscription management and recurring billing platform, said that Apple’s continued push into subscriptions is only one example of the allure of subscription eCommerce. For Apple, the watches, the fitness and the bundles play into a must-have strategy that favors recurring revenues over hardware hits. As we noted earlier this year, Apple said in its most recent earnings report that its services top line was up almost 15 percent year over year, and had met (ahead of schedule) its stated target (outlined back in 2016) of doubling this revenue stream by the close of 2020. Paid accounts, up 30 percent year on year, stand at 550 million. As Bogosian noted to Webster, the bundles could give a boost to the tech behemoth’s hardware business, spurring “automatic upgrades to products at a certain period of time, so they don't have to worry as much about the volatility of market acceptance around new releases of products.” Apple has demonstrated that it knows it must get its consumers into a “set it and forget it,” Big-Tech-as-a-Service mindset. Now comes the hard part: getting there. Now, about those iPhones… —————————— LIVE PYMNTS TV OCTOBER SERIES: POWERING THE DIGITAL SHIFT – B2B PAYMENTS 2021 Banks, corporates and even regulators now recognize the imperative to modernize — not just digitize —the infrastructures and workflows that move money and data between businesses domestically and cross-border. Together with Visa, PYMNTS invites you to a month-long series of livestreamed programs on these issues as they reshape B2B payments. Masters of modernization share insights and answer questions during a mix of intimate fireside chats and vibrant virtual roundtables. Recommended for you

urn:contentItem:60JT-8XW1-JCMN-Y2GP-00000-00Apple's Market Cap Nears $2 Trillion, CEO Tim Cook's Net Worth Soars to $1 Billion2020-08-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisApple's Market Cap Nears $2 Trillion, CEO Tim Cook's Net Worth Soars to $1 BillionUsman Qureshi

Aug 10, 2020( iPhone in Canada: http://www.iphoneincanada.ca/ Delivered by Newstex) Following a 5% hike in Apple's share price last week, CEO Tim Cook's net worth has surpassed $1 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index[1], making him a memberof one of the most elite clubs of CEOs who didn't found the companies they run.'Cook's net worth estimate is based on an analysis of regulatory filings and applying the market performance of a typical wealthy investor to his proceeds from share sales. Cook, 59, said in 2015 that he plans to give most of his fortune away and has already gifted million of dollars worth of Apple shares.

His wealth could be lower if he's made other undisclosed charitable gifts.' Meanwhile, Apple is on the verge of hitting yet anothermarket milestone i.e. market value of nearly $2 trillion. The company was valued at about $350 billion when Steve Jobs died.Even though over the past decade, Apple hasn't revealed a new product as groundbreaking as the iPhone, the company still has thrived. Cook has overseen the development of devices like the iPhone X and Apple Watch, new services like Apple Music, and research on new frontiers like self-driving cars, and augmented-reality glasses. Apple's market value and Cook's growing net worth reflect the rise of the FAANG stocks. It also comes as Cook and his fellow Big Tech CEOs Jeff Bezos, Sundar Pichai, and Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook, face antitrust investigations[2] into what their critics characterize as monopolistic powers. [ 1]: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-10/apple-s-cook-becomes-billionaire-via-the-less-traveled-ceo-route [ 2]: https://www.iphoneincanada.ca/news/cook-opening-statement/

Following a 5% hike in Apple’s share price last week, CEO Tim Cook’s net worth has surpassed $1 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index , making him...

Following a 5% hike in Apple’s share price last week, CEO Tim Cook’s net worth has surpassed $1 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index , making him a member of one of the most elite clubs of CEOs who didn’t found the companies they run. “Co...

Following a 5% hike in Apple’s share price last week, CEO Tim Cook’s net worth has surpassed $1 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index , making him a member of one of the most elite clubs of CEOs who didn’t found the companies they run. “Cook’s net worth estimate is based on an analysis of regulatory filings and applying the market performance of a typical wealthy investor to his proceeds from share sales. Cook, 59, said in 2015 that he plans to give most of his fortune away and has already gifted million of dollars worth of Apple shares. His wealth could be lower if he’s made other undisclosed charitable gifts.” Meanwhile, Apple is on the verge of hitting yet another market milestone i.e. market value of nearly $2 trillion. The company was valued at about $350 billion when Steve Jobs died. Even though over the past decade, Apple hasn’t revealed a new product as groundbreaking as the iPhone, the company still has thrived. Cook has overseen the development of devices like the iPhone X and Apple Watch, new services like Apple Music, and research on new frontiers like self-driving cars, and augmented-reality glasses. Apple’s market value and Cook’s growing net worth reflect the rise of the FAANG stocks. It also comes as Cook and his fellow Big Tech CEOs Jeff Bezos, Sundar Pichai, and Mark Zuckerberg of

urn:contentItem:60JS-N6F1-F07F-83J6-00000-00Apple’s Market Cap Nears $2 Trillion, CEO Tim Cook’s Net Worth Soars to $1 Billion2020-08-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisBLOGApple’s Market Cap Nears $2 Trillion, CEO Tim Cook’s Net Worth Soars to $1 BillionUsman Qureshi

Following a 5% hike in Apple’s share price last week, CEO Tim Cook’s net worth has surpassed $1 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index , making him a...

Following a 5% hike in Apple’s share price last week, CEO Tim Cook’s net worth has surpassed $1 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index , making him a member of one of the most elite clubs of CEOs who didn’t found the companies they run. “Co...

Following a 5% hike in Apple’s share price last week, CEO Tim Cook’s net worth has surpassed $1 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index , making him a member of one of the most elite clubs of CEOs who didn’t found the companies they run. “Cook’s net worth estimate is based on an analysis of regulatory filings and applying the market performance of a typical wealthy investor to his proceeds from share sales. Cook, 59, said in 2015 that he plans to give most of his fortune away and has already gifted million of dollars worth of Apple shares. His wealth could be lower if he’s made other undisclosed charitable gifts.” Meanwhile, Apple is on the verge of hitting yet another market milestone i.e. market value of nearly $2 trillion. The company was valued at about $350 billion when Steve Jobs died. Even though over the past decade, Apple hasn’t revealed a new product as groundbreaking as the iPhone, the company still has thrived. Cook has overseen the development of devices like the iPhone X and Apple Watch, new services like Apple Music, and research on new frontiers like self-driving cars, and augmented-reality glasses. Apple’s market value and Cook’s growing net worth reflect the rise of the FAANG stocks. It also comes as Cook and his fellow Big Tech CEOs Jeff Bezos, Sundar Pichai, and Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook, face antitrust investigations into what their critics characterize as monopolistic powers.

urn:contentItem:5XGB-K971-JCJY-G1CT-00000-00Apple's metal credit cards accused of being 'sexist'2019-11-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:45ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCEVersion:5Apple's metal credit cards accused of being 'sexist'By Olivia Rudgard, US Technology Reporter

Apple's new credit card is under investigation for gender discrimination after complaints from customers including the company's co-founder Steve Wozniak.

The inventor of Apple's first computers said he had been offered   10 times the credit limit of his wife Janet Hill despite the fact that the couple had "no separate bank or credit card accounts or any separate assets".

The row was initially sparked after tech entrepreneur David Heinemeier Hansson complained on Twitter that he had been given 20 times the credit limit of his wife when applying for the metal card. 

"My wife and I filed joint tax returns, live in a community-property state, and have been married for a long time. 

"Yet Apple's black box algorithm thinks I deserve 20x the credit limit she does. No appeals work," the Danish entrepreneur said. 

Both men said they had complained to the California company's customer service representatives to no avail, though Mr Hansson's wife was offered a higher limit to match his after he posted the viral tweets. 

The same thing happened to us. I got 10x the credit limit. We have no separate bank or credit card accounts or any separate assets. Hard to get to a human for a correction though. It's big tech in 2019.- Steve Wozniak (@stevewoz) https://twitter.com/stevewoz/status/1193330241478901760?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwNovember 10, 2019

They criticised the company for pointing to opaque "black box" algorithms to explain the decisions.

A New York regulator has announced an investigation, and invited customers who think they have been discriminated against to get in touch.

Linda A Lacewell, superintendent of New York State department of financial services, said: "We will work to investigate what may have gone wrong, and if the algorithm used by Apple Card did indeed promote unlawful discrimination we will take appropriate action."

At a glance | Apple Card

Apple's credit card, launched in August in the US, is run in partnership with Wall Street bank Goldman Sachs. It is not yet available in the UK.

A spokesman for Goldman Sachs said: "Our credit decisions are based on a customer's creditworthiness and not on factors like gender, race, age, sexual orientation or any other basis prohibited by law."

Technology companies have previously been criticised for relying on artificial intelligence to make decisions without ensuring that the algorithms were not discriminating against certain groups. 

Last year Amazon cancelled a recruitment AI project after it discovered it was discriminating against female candidates.
